publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: _SIgnor Alphonſo, ye are too rugged to her,
Believe too full of harſneſſe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes, it ſeemes ſo.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A father of ſo ſweet a child, ſo happy,
(Fy Sir) ſo excellent in all endowments,
In bleſſedneſſe of beauty, ſuch a mirror.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: She is a foole, away.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Can ye be angry?
Can any wind blow rough, upon a bloſſom
So faire, and tender? Can a Fathers nature,
A noble Fathers too?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: All this is but prating:
Let her be rul'd; let her obſerve my humor,
With tny eyes let her ſee; with my eares liſten;
I am her Father: I begot her, bred her,
And I will make her.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: No doubt ye may compell her,
But what a miſceivous, unhappy fortune
May wayt upon this wil of yours, as commonly
Such forcings ever end in hates, and ruines.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Is't not a man I wiſh her to? a ſtrong man?
What can ſhe have? what could ſhe have? a Gentleman?
A yong man? and an able-man? a rich man?
A handſome man? a valiant man? do you marke me?
None of your peeced-companions, your pin'd-Gallants,
That flie to fitters, with every flaw of weather:
None of your impt bravados: what can ſhe ask more?
Is not a mettal'd-man fit for a woman?
A ſtrong chindman? i'le not be foold, nor flurted.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I grant ye Rodorgio is all theſe
And a brave Gentleman: muſt it therefore follow
Upon neceſſity ſhe muſt doate upon him?
Will ye allow no liberty in chooſing?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Alas ſhe is tender yet.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Enough enough, enough Sir:
She is malliable; ſhee'l endure the hammer,
And why not that ſtrong workeman that ſtrikes deepeſt?
Let me know that? ſhe is fifteen, with the vantage,
And if ſhe be not ready now for mannage—

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You know he is a baniſh'd man: an out-Law;
And how he lives: his nature rough, and bloody
By cuſtomary rapines: now, her ſweet humor
That is as eaſy as a calme, and peacefull,
All her affections, like the dewes on Roſes,
Faire as the flowers themſelves: as ſweet, and gentle:
How would you have theſe meet?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A bed, a bed ſir:
Let her be the faireſt Roſe, and the ſweeteſt,
Yet I know this faire roſe muſt have her prickles:
I grant ye Rodorigo is an out-Law,
An eaſie compoſition cals him in again,
He is a valiant man, and he is a rich man,
And loves the foole: a little rough by cuſtome:
Shee'l like him ten times better. Shee'l doat upon him,
If ere they come to grapling, run mad for him;
But there is an other in the wind, ſome caſtrell
That hovers over her, and dares her dayly,
Some flickring ſlave.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I dare not think ſo poorely.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Something there is, and muſt be: but I ſhall ſente it
And hunt it narrowly.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I never ſaw her yet
Make offer at the leaſt glance of affection,
But ſtill ſo modeſt, wiſe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: They are wiſe to gull us,
There was a fellow, old Ferandos ſon,
I muſt confeſſe handſome, but my enemy,
And the whole family, I hate yong Pedro:
That fellow I have ſeen her gaze upon,
And turn, and gaze again, and make ſuch offers
As if ſhe would ſhoot her eyes like meteors at him:
But that cauſe ſtands removed.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: You need not doubt him.
For long ſince as 'twas thought on a griev'd conſcience,
He left his father, and his friends: more pitty:
For truth reports he was a noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let him be what he wil: he was a begger,
And there i'le leave him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The more the Court muſt anſwer;
But certainly I think, though ſhe might favour him,
And love his goodneſſe, as he was an honeſt man:
She never with looſe eyes ſtuck on his perſon.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She is ſo full of conſcience too, and charity,
And outward holineſſe, ſhe will undoe me:
Relieves more beggers, then an hoſpitall; En. Alinda, and Juletta.
And all poor rogues, that can but ſay their prayers,
And tune their pipes to Lamentations,
She thinks ſhe is bound to dance to: good morrow to you,
And that's as ye deſerve too: you know my mind,
And ſtuddy to obſerve it: doe it cheerfully.
And readily, and home.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I ſhall obey ye.
But noble ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come, come, away with your flatteries,
And your fine phraſes,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Pray ye be gentle to her:

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I know 'em; and know your feates: if you will find me
Noble and loving, ſeek me in your duty,
You know I am too indulgent.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Alas poor Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: To your devotions: I take no good thing from you
Come Gentlemen; leave pittying, and moaning of her,
And prayſing of her vertues: and her whym-whams,
It makes her proud, and ſturdy:

sp.speaker: Seb. Cur.
sp.l: Good houres wait on ye. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I thank ye Gentlemen: I want ſuch comforts:
I would thank you too father: but your cruelty
Hath almoſt made me ſenſeleſſe of my duty,
Yet ſtill I muſt know: would J had known nothing;
What Poor attend my charity to day, wench?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Of all ſorte, Madam; your open handed bounty
Makes 'em flock every houre: ſome worth your pitty,
But others that have made a trade of begging.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Wench, if they ask it truly, I muſt give it:
It takes away the holy uſe of charity
To examine wants.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would you would be merry:
A cheerfull-giving hand, as I think, Madam,
Requires a heart as cheerfull.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Alas Iuletta,
What is there to be merry at? what joy now,
Unleſſe we foole our own afflictions,
And make them ſhew ridiculous?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure Madam,
You could not ſeeme thus ſerious, if you were married,
Thus ſad, and full of thoughts.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Married? to whom, wench?
Thou thinkſt if there be a yong handſome fellow
As thoſe are plentifull, our cares are quenched then.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Madam, I think a luſty handſome fellow
If he be kind, and loving, and a right one,
Is even as good a pill, to purge this melancholy,
As ever Galen gave, I am ſure more naturall:
And merrier for the heart, then Wine and Saffron:
Madam, wantone youth is ſuch a Cataplaſme.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Who has bin thy tutor wench?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Even my own thoughts, Lady:
For though J be bard the liberty of talking,
Yet I can think unhappily, and as near the mark, Madam,
'Faith, marry, and be merry.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Who wil have me?
Who wil be troubled with a tettiſh Girle?
It may be proud, and to that vice expencefull?
Who can aſſure himſelfe, I ſhall live honeſt?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Let every man take his fortune:

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And o' my conſcience
If once I grow to breeding, a whole Kingdome
Wil not containe my ſtock.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The more the merrier:
'Tis brave to be a mother of new Nations.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Why, I ſhould bury a hundred husbands.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tis no matter:
As long as ye leave ſufficient men to ſtock ye.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Is this thy mirth? are theſe the joyes of marriage?
Away light-headed foole; are theſe contentments?
If I could finde a man.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You may a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Meere men I know I may: and there a woman
Has liberty, (at leaſt ſhee'l venture for it,)
To be a monſter and become the time too;
But to enjoy a man, from whoſe example
(As from a compaſſe) we may ſteer our fortunes,
Our actions, and our age; and ſafe arive at
A memory that ſhall become our aſhes,
Such things are few, and far to ſeek; to finde one
That can but rightly mannage the wild beaſt, woman,
And ſweetly govern with her. But no more of this, wench,
Tis not for thy diſcourſe: Lets in, and ſee
What poor afflicted wait our charity. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter a Porter, 4. Beggers, Pedro, and a Pilgrime.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Stand off, and keep your Rancks: twenty foot further:
There Iouſe your ſelves with reaſon, & diſcretion.
The Sun ſhines warm: the farther ſtill the better,
Your beaſts wil bolt anon, and then tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: 1. Beg.
sp.l: Heaven bleſſe our Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Does the crack go that way?
'Twil be o'th o'ther ſide anon.
Pray ye friend.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Your friend? and why your friend? why, goodman turncoat
What doſt thou ſee within me, or without me,
Or what itch doſt thou know upon me, tell me,
That I ſhould be thy friend? what do I look like
Any of thy acquaintance hoong in Gibbets?
Haſt thou any Friends, Kindred, or Alliance,
Or any higher ambition, then an almes-basket?

sp.speaker: 2. Beg.
sp.l: I would be your worſhips friend.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: So ye ſhall Sirra,
When I quarter the ſame louſe with ye.
Tis twelve o'clock.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Tis ever ſo with thee, when thou haſt done ſcratching,
For that provokes thy ſtomach to ring noon;
O the infinite Seas of porridge thou haſt ſwallowd!
And yet thou lookſt as if they had bin but Gliſters;
Thou feedſt abundance; thou hadſt need of ſuſtenance;
Almes do you call it to relieve theſe Raſcals? Enter Al|phonſo Curio, Seberto.
No●hing but a generall rot of ſheep can ſatisfie'em.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: Did not I tel you, how ſhe would undo me?
What Marts of Rogues, and Beggers?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Tis charity
Methinks, you are bound to love her for—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes, I warrant ye,
If men could ſale to heaven in porridge pots,
With maſts of Beef, and Mutton, what a voyage ſhould I make?
What are all theſe?
Poore people, and 't like your worſhip.
Wretched poor people.
Very hungry people.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And very Louſy.
Yes forſooth, ſo, ſo.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I'le undertake five hundred head about 'em,
And that's no needy Graſier.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Strangers that come to wonder at your charity,
Yet people poore enough to beg a bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Uſe them with favour, ſir, their ſhews are reverent,
It ſeemes ye are holy Pilgrimes?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Ye gheſſe right ſir,
And bound far off, to offer our devotions.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What make ye this way? we keep no Reliques here,
Nor holy Shrines.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: The holieſt we ere heard of;
Ye keep a living monument of goodneſſe,
A Daughter of that pious excellence,
The very Shrines of Saints ſinck at her vertues,
And ſwear they cannot hold pace with her pieties,
We come to ſee this Lady: not with prophane eyes,
Nor wanton bloods, to do at upon her beauties,
But through our tedious wayes to beg her bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This is a new way of begging, and a neat one,
And this cries money for reward: good ſtore too;
Theſe commendations beg not with bag, and bottle;
Well, well, the ſainting of this woman (Gentlemen)
I know what it muſt come too: theſe women ſaints
Are plaguy heavy ſaints: they out-waigh a he-ſaint
Three thouſand thick; I know: I feele.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ye are more afraid then hurt ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Have you your commendations ready too?
He bowes, and nods.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A handſome well built perſon.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What Country-craver are you? nothing but motion?
A puppet-Pilgrim?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Hee's a ſtranger ſir;
This foure dayes I have traveld in his company,
But little of his buſines, or his Language
As yet, I have underſtood.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Both yong, and handſome,
Only the Sun has bin too ſaucy with him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Would ye have money ſir, or meat? what kind of bleſſing
Does your devotion looke for? Still more ducking?
Be there any ſaints, that underſtand by ſignes only?
More motion yet? this is the prettieſt Pilgrim,
The pinck of pilgrims: ile be for ye ſir;
Do ye diſcourſe with ſignes? ye are hartly welcome:
A poor viaticum; very good gold ſir;
But holy men affect a better treaſure.
I kept it for your goodnes, but neertheleſſe
Since it can prove but burthen ſome to your holines,
And you affect light prayer, fit for carriage,
I'le put this up againe.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Ye are too unreverent..

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ye talk too broad; muſt I give way, and wealth too
To every toy, that carries a grave ſeeming?
Muſt my good angels wait on him? if the proud hilding
Would yeild but to my wil, and know her duty
I knew what I would ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good ſir, be patient,
The wrongs ye do theſe men, may light on you,
Too heavy too: and then you wil wiſh you had ſaid leſſe;
A comly and ſweet uſage becomes ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: We ſhall have half the Kingdom ſtrangers ſhortly,
And this fond prodigality be ſufferd;
But I muſt be an aſſe, ſee 'hem relieved, ſirah;
If I were yong again, I would ſooner get beare whelps,
And ſafer too, them any of theſe She-ſaints,
But I will break her,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Such a face for certain.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Me thinks I have ſeen it too: but we are cozend;
But fair befall thee Pilgrim, thou lookſt lovely. Exit

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Will ye troop up, ye porridge Regiment? Enter Alinda Iuletta.
Captain Poors quarter wil ye move?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ye dull Knave,
Are not theſe wretches ſerved yet?

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: 'Bleſſe my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Do you make ſport ſir, with their miſeries?
Ye drouſie rogue.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: They are too high fed, Madam,
Their ſtomacks are a'ſleep yet.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Serve 'hem plentifully,
Or i'le ſerve you out next: even out o' dores, ſirah;
And ſerve 'em quickly too.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Heaven bleſſe the Lady.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Bleſſe the good end I meane it for.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would I knew it:
If it be for any mans ſake, i'le cry amen too,
Well Madam, ye have even as pretty a port of pentioners.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Vain-glory would ſeek more, and handſomer. Ex.
But I appeale to vertue what my end is; Beggers
What men are theſe?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It ſeems they are holy Pilgrims:
That handſome youth ſhould ſuffer ſuch a pennance,
Would I were even the ſaint they make their vowes too,
How eaſily I would grant.

sp.speaker: Pil,
sp.l: Heavens grace in-wheele ye:
And all good thoughts, and prayers dwell about ye,
Abundance be your friend; and holy charity
Be ever at your hand' to crown ye glorious.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I thank ye ſir; peace guid your travels too,
And what you wiſh for moſt, end all your trobles;
Remember me by this: and in your prayers
When your ſtrong heart melts, mediate my poor fortunes.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: All my devotions wait upon your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Are ye of this Country, ſir?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Yes, worthieſt Lady,
But far off bred: my fortunes farther from me.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Gentle, I dare believe.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I have liv'd freer.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I am no inquiſitor, that were too curious:
What ever vow, or pennance puls ye on ſir;
Conſcience, or love, or ſtubborn diſobedience,
The ſaint ye kneel too, hear, and eaſe your travels.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Yours neer begin: and thus I ſeal my prayers. Ex.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: How conſtantly this man looks? how he ſighes?
Some great affliction hatches his devotions,
Right holy ſir: how yong, and ſweet he ſuffers?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Would I might ſuffer with him.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: He turns from us:
Alas he weeps too: ſomething preſſes him
He would reveale, but dare not; ſir, be comforted,
Ye come for that: and take it: if it be want, ſir,
To me yee appear ſo worthy of relieving,
I am your ſteward: ſpeak, and take: he's dumb ſtill:
Now as I have a faith this man ſo ſtirs me,
His modeſty makes me affraid I have treſpaſſed.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Would he would ſtir me too: I like his ſhape well.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: May be he would ſpeak alone: go off Iuletta,
Afflicted hearts fear their own motions,
Be not far off.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Would I were neerer to him,
A yong ſmug handſome holines has no fellow. Exit

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Why do you grieve? do you find your pennance ſharp?
Orare the vowes ye have made, too mighty for ye?
Do's not the world allure ye to look back
And ſorrow for the ſweet time ye have loſt?
Ye are yong, and fair; be not deluded, ſir;
A manly made up heart contemnes theſe ſhadows,
And yours appeares no leſſe: greifes for your fears,
For houres ill-ſpent, for wrongs don raſh, and rudely,
For fowle contempts for faiths ill violated,
Become fears well: I dare not task your Goodnes:
And then a ſorrow ſhewes in his true glory
VVhen the whole heart is excellently ſorry.
I pray ye be comforted.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I am, deer Lady,
And ſuch a comfort ye have caſt upon me,
That though I ſtruggle with mine own calamities
Too mighty, and too many for my mannage,
And though, like angry waves, they curld upon me
Contending proudly who ſhould firſt devour me,
Yet I would ſtem their danger.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: He ſpeaks nobly:
What do ye want?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: All that can make me happy:
I want my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Your ſelf? who rob'd ye Pilgrim?
Why does he look ſo conſtantly upon me?
I want my ſelfe: indeed, you holy wounderers
Are ſaid to ſeek much: but to ſeek your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I ſeek my ſelf; and am but my ſelfs-ſhadow:
Have loſt my ſelf; and now am not ſo noble.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I ſeek my ſelf: ſomething I yet remember
That bears that Motto; 'tis not he: he is yonger,
And far more tender: for that ſelf-ſake (Pilgrim)
Be who it will, take this.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Your hand I dare take,
That be far from me, Lady, thus I kiſſe it,
And thus I bleſſe it too; be conſtant fair ſtill:
Be good, and live to be a great example. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: One word more (Pilgrim) has amazd me strangly,
Be conſtant faire ſtill: tis the poſſe here:
And here without, Be good: he wept to ſee me Enter Iuletta

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Take this Key, and fetch me
The Marygold Jewell that lies in my little Cabinet:
I think tis that: what eyes had I, to miſſe him?
O' me, what thoughts? he had no beard then, and
As I remember well, he was more ruddy. En Iuletta
If this be he, he has a manly face yet
A goodly ſhape.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Here Madam?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Let me ſee it:
Tis ſo, too true: It muſt be he, or nothing,
He ſpak the words juſt as they ſtand engraved here:
I ſeek my ſelf, and am but my ſelfes-ſhadow:
Alas poor man: didſt thou not meet him, Iuletta?
The Pilgrim wench?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: He went by long ago, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I forgot to give him ſomething.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: 'Twas ill done Lady:
For, o' my troth, he is the handſomeſt man
I ſaw this many a day: would he had all my wealth,
And me to boote: what ayles ſhe to grow ſullen?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.p: Come, I forgot; but I will recompence it. Exeunt

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Alphonſo, Curio, Seberto, Iuletta, Porter, and ſervants.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Can ſhe ſlip through a cat-hole? tel me that: reſolve me;
Can the ſly ith ayre? is ſhe a thing inviſible?
Gon, and none know it?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ye amaz your ſervants.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Some pelting rogue has watch'd her houre of itching,
And clawd her; clawd her: do you mark me, clawd her;
Some that I foſter up.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: They are all here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let 'em be where they will, they are arrant raſcals,
And by this hand i'le hang 'em all.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Deale calmely:
You will not give 'em time to anſwer ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I'le choak 'hem: famiſh 'em: what ſay you wag-taile?
You knew her mind: you were of councell with her,
Tell me: and tell me true.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Aske with diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Diſcretion? hang diſcretion, hang ye all:
Let me know where ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Would you know o' me ſir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O' thee ſir: I, o' thee ſir: what art thou ſir?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hir woman ſir, and 't like your worſhip, ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Her band, her fidle-stick.
Her Lady-fayry, to oyl the dores o' nights,
That they may open with diſcretion,
Her Gin, her Nut-crack,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tis very well ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thou lieſt; tis dan nal le ill, tis moſt abhominaable:
Will ye confes (Thing)

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Say I were gulty, ſir?
I would be hangd before I would confeſſe:
Is this a World to confeſſe in?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Deale directly.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes, if my matter lie direct before me:
But when I am forc'd, and ferryted.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Tell me the truth,
And as I live, i'le give thee a new petticote.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And you would give me ten, I would not tell ye,
Truths bear a greater price, then you are aware of.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Deale modeſtly.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I doe not pluck my cloths up.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What ſay you ſirha? you? or you? are ye dumb all?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I ſaw her laſt night, and 't ſhall like your worſhip
When I ſerv'd in her Livery.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What's that, ſirha?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Her Chamber pot, and 't pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A new Livery.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where lay ſhe? who lay with her?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: In truth not I ſir:
I lay with my fellow Fredrick, in the flea-chamber
And 't like your worſhip, we are almoſt worried.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I left her by her ſelf, in her own cloſet,
And there I thought ſhe had ſlept.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why lay you from her?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It was her will I ſhould: ſhe is my Miſtris,
And my part is obedience.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Were all the dores lockt?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: All mine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And mine: ſhe could not get out thoſe wayes
Unles ſhe lept the wals: and thoſe are higher
Then any womans courage dare aſpire at.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come, you muſt know.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Conceale it not, but deale plaine.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If I did know, and her truſt lay upon me,
Not all your angers, nor your flatteries
Should make me ſpeak, but having no more intereſt
Then I may well deliver to the aire,
I'le tell ye what I know: and tell it liberally,
I think ſhe is gon, becauſe we cannot find her;
I think ſhe is weary of your tyranny,
And therefore gon: may be ſhe is in love:
May be in love, where you ſhow no great liking,
And therefore gon: May be, ſome point of conſcience,
Or vowd devotion.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Theſe are nothing, minion;
You that can aime at theſe, muſt know the truth too.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Any more truth then this if I know, hang me,
Or where to ſearch for it, if I make a lie
To gaine your love, and envy my beſt Miſtris,
Pin me againſt a wall, with my heel's upwards.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Out of my dores.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That's all my poor petition:
For if your houſe were gold, and ſhe not in it,
Sir, I ſhould count it but a cage to whiſtle in.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Whore, if ſhe be above ground, I wil have her.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would live in a cole-pit, then, were I your daughter.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Certaine ſhe dos not know Sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Hang her, hang her:
She knowes too much: ſearch all the houſe; all corners,
And where tis poſſible ſhe may goe out, Ex. ſervants.
If I do finde your tricks.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Reward me for 'hem.
Or if I had ſuch tricks, you could diſcover
So weak, and ſleightly woven, you might look through,
All the young Girles ſhould hoot me out oth' Pariſh.
You are my Maſter, but ye owne an anger
Becomes a School-boy, that hath loſt his Apples;
Will ye force things into our knowledges?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come hither Juletta; thou didſt love me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And do ſtill:
You are my Ladies father, and I reverence ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thou wouldſt have pleas'd my humor.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Any good way,
That carried not ſuſpition in't: or flattery,
Or faile of truſt.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come, come, thou wouldſt have.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stay ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And thou haſt felt my bounty for't, and ſhalt doe.
Doſt thou want Clothes or Money?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Both.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Shalt have both.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But not this way: I had rather be an Adamite
And bring Fig-leaves into faſhion again.
If you were young ſir,
Handſome, and fitted to a womans appetite;
And I a giddy-headed girle, that car'd for nothing,
Much might be done; then you might fumble with me,
And thinke to grope out matters of ſome moment,
Which now you will put too ſhort for:
For what you have ſeen hitherto,
And know by me, has been but honeſt ſervice,
Which I dare pin ith' market-place to anſwer;
And let the world, the fleſh and divell examine it,
And come you in too, I dare stand your ſtricteſt.
And ſo much good may doe you, with your dreames of curteſie.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This is moſt monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sure ſhe do's not know ſir:
She durſt not be ſo confident and guilty.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How now; what newes? what hopes and ſteps diſ|covered?
Speake any thing thats good, that tends to th' matter;
Doe you ſtand ſtaring ſtill?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: We are no Gods ſir,
To ſay ſhe is here, or there: and what ſhe is doing;
But we have ſearch'd.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I am ſure ſhe is not ith' Cellar;
For looke you ſir, if ſhe had been ith' Cellar—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am ſure thou haſt been there.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: As I carried the matter,
For I ſearch'd every piece of Wine; yes ſure ſir,
And every little Tereſſe that could but teſtifie:
And I drew hard to bolt her out.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Away with him;
Fling him ith' Haymow, let him lie a mellowing;
He ſtinks of Muſkadel like an Engliſh Chriſtmas:
Are theſe your cares? your ſervices?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Pray ye heare ſir,
We have found where ſhe went out; her very footing.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where where? goe on.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Obſerve then wth more ſlaiedneſſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Searching the garden: at the little Poſterne
That opens to the Parke, we firſt diſcovered it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A little foot?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: It muſt be hers, or none ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How far beyond that?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: To the Parke it leads us,
But there the ground being hard, we could not marke it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She alwaies kept that Key: I was a coxcomb,
A foole, an aſſe, to give a girle that liberty:
Saddle my Horſes, rogues, ye drunken varlets:
Your precious diligence lies in Pint-pots,
Your brains in Butts, my horſes, ye pin-buttocks.
You'l beare me company?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We dare not leave ye,
Unleſſe we found a quieter ſoule within ye.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: If we may do the Lady any ſervice,
Sweet, gentle ſoule.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I ſay againe, my horſes:
Are ye ſo hot? have ye your private pilgrimages?
Muſt ye be Jumping-Jone? Ile wander with ye:
Ile jump ye, and Ile joggle ye: my horſes;
And keep me this young Lirry-poope within dores,
I will diſcover, dame.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis fit you ſhould ſir,
If ye knew what: Well Love, if thou bee'ſt with her,
Or what power elſe that armes her reſolution,
Conduct her faire, and keepe her from this mad man,
Direct her to her wiſhes: dwell about her
That no diſhonourable end ore-take her,
Danger, or want: and let me try my fortune.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You know the place we meet in?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We ſhall hit it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And as ye are honeſt Gentlemen, endeavour.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: We'l ſearch the beſt we can: if ſhe light in our hands.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Tie her to th' horſe taile.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We know how to uſe her,
But not your way, for all your ſtate.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Make haſte there:
And get you in, and looke to th'houſe. If you ſtir out, Damſell,
Or ſet o' foot any new motion this way,
When I come home, (which ſhall be ſuddenly)
You know my mind: if you doe play the raſcall,
I have my eyes and eares in ſundry places,
If ye doe praunce.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I ſhall doe that, that's fit, ſir:
And fit to croſſe your fooleries; Ile faile elſe.
And ſo Ile to my chamber. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: To your prayers,
And leave your ſtubborne tricks: She is not far yet,
She cannot be; and we dividing ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Keep her from thy hands, I beſeech.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Our horſes;
Come cheerfully. Ile teach her to run gadding. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Out-l.
sp.l: Captaine, y'are not merry.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: We get nothing,
We have no ſport; whoring, apd drinking ſpoiles us,
We keep no guards.
There come no paſſengers,
Merchants, nor Gentlemen, nor whoſoever,
But we have Tribute.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And whilſt we ſpend that idlely,
We let thoſe paſſe that carry the beſt purchaſe.
Ile have all ſearch'd & brought in; Rogues, and Beggars,
Have got the tricke now to become Banck-maſters.
Ile have none ſcape: onely my friends, and neighbours,
That may deliver to the King my innocence;
Thoſe I would have regarded; tis policy.
But otherwiſe nor gravities, nor ſhadows,
Appeare they how they will, that may have purſes,
For they ſhall pay.
Ye ſpeake now like a Captaine.
And if we ſpare, flea us, and coyn our Caſſoks;
Will ye looke blith?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You heare no preparation
The King intends againſt us yet?
Not a word ſir.
Good man, he's troubled with matter of more moment,
Hummings of higher nature vex his braines, ſir;
Doe not we fee his garriſons?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Who are out now?
Good fellows ſir, that if there be any purchaſe ſtirring
Will ſtrike it dead; Jaques and Loper, Lads
That know their quarters, as they know their knapſaks;
And will not off.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Where is the boy ye brought me?
A pretty lad, and of a quicke capacity,
And bred up neatly.
He's within at meat, ſir,
The knave is hungry: yet he ſeaſons all
He eates or drinkes with many teares and ſighings,
The ſaddeſt appetite I ever look'd on;
The boy is young, tis feare and want of company
He knows and loves: uſe him not rough, nor harſhly,
He will be quickly bold; Ile entertaine him:
I want a pretty Boy to waite upon me,
And when I am ſad or ſleepy, to prate to me;
Beſides there's ſomething in his face, I like well.
And ſtill the more I looke, more like; let him want nothing,
And uſe him gently, all.
Here's a ſmall Box, ſir,
We tooke about him, which he griev'd to part with,
May be ſome wealth.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Alas, ſome little money
The poore knave carried to defray his lodgings,
Ile give it him againe, and adde unto it.
'Twere ſin to open ſuch a petty purchaſe.
sp.stage: Enter Loper and Jaques, with Pedro.
sp.l: How now, who is this? what have you brought me Souldiers?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We know not wel what: a ſtrange ſtaving fellow,
Sullen enough I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Where tooke ye him?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Upon the skirt o'th wood, veiwing, and gaping,
And ſometime ſtanding ſtill, as if he had meant
To view the beſt acceſſes to our quarters;
Money he has enough: and when we threatned him,
He ſmil'd, and yeilded; but not one word utter'd.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: His habit ſaies he's holy: if his heart
Keep that proportion too, 'tis beſt ye free him,
We keep his Wallet here: I am ſure tis heavy.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Pilgrime: come hither ſir; Are you a Pilgrime?
A piece of pretty holineſſe: doe you ſhrinke ſir?
A ſmug young Saint. What Countrey were you born in?
Ye have a Spaniſh face: In a dumb Province?
And had your mother too this excellent vertue?
No tongue do you ſay? ſure ſhe was a matchleſſe woman;
What a ſine family is this man ſprung from!
Certaine he was begotten in a calme,
When all was huſht: the Midwife was dumb Midnight;
Are ye ſeal'd up? or doe you ſcorne to anſwer?
Ye are in my hands, and I have medicines for ye
Can make ye ſpeake: pull off his Bonnet, Souldiers;
Ye have a ſpeaking face.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am ſure a handſome:
This Pilgrime cannot want She-Saints to pray to.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Stand neerer: ha?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Come, do your worſt; I am ready.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Is your tongue found? go off, and let me talk with him;
An keepe your watches round.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are ready Captaine.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: So: now what are ye?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Am I?
My habit ſhewes me what I am.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thy heart
A deſperate foole, and ſo thy fate ſhall tell thee;
What devill brought thee hither? for I know thee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know thou doſt: and ſince it is my fortune
To light into thy fingers; I muſt thinke too
The moſt malicious of all devils brought me,
Yet ſome men ſay thou art Noble.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Not to thee,
That were a benefit to mocke the giver:
Thy father hates my friends, and family,
And thou haſt been the heire of all this malice.
Can two ſuch ſtormes meet then, and part with kiſſing?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You have the mightier hand.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: And ſo Ile uſe it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I cannot hinder ye: leſſe can I beg
Submiſſive at his knees that knows not honour;
That bears the ſtamp of man, and not his nature;
Ye may doe what ye pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I will doe all.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And when you have done all, which is my poore ruine,
(For farther your baſe malice cannot venture)
Diſhonours ſelfe will cry you out a coward.
Hadſt thou been brave, and noble and an Enemy,
Thou wouldſt have ſought me whilſt I carried Armes,
Whilſt my good Sword was my profeſſion,
And then have cried out Pedro, I defie thee;
Then ſtuck Alphonſo's quarrell on the point,
The mercenary anger thou ſerv'ſt under
To get his daughter. Then thou ſhouldſt have brav'd me,
And arm'd with all thy families hate upon me,
Done ſomething worthy feat: Now poore and baſely
Thou ſetſt Toyles to betray me; and like the Peſant,
That dares not meet the Lyon in the face,
Digſt crafty pit-fals: Thou ſham'ſt the Spaniſh honour:
Thou haſt neither poynt of man, nor conſcience in thee.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sir, ſir, y'are brave; ye plead now in a Sanctuary;
You think your Pilgrimes bulwarke can defend ye:
You will not finde it ſo.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I looke not for't.
The more unhallowed ſoule haſt thou to offer it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: When you were braveſt, ſir, and your Sword ſharpeſt,
I durſt affront ye: when the Court Sunne guilded ye,
And every cry was the young hopefull Pedro,
Alonſos ſprightly ſonne; then durſt I meet ye,
When you were Maſter of this fame, and faſhion,
And all your glories in the full Meridian,
The Kings proof-favour buckled on your body;
Had we then come to competition,
Which I have often ſought.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And I deſired too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You ſhould have ſeen this Sword, how ere you ſleight it,
And felt it too; ſharper then ſorrow felt it,
In execution quicker then thy ſcornes;
Thou ſhouldſt have ſeen all this, and ſhrunke to ſee it.
Then like a Gentleman I would have us'd thee,
And given thee the faire fortune of thy being,
Then with a Souldiers Arme I had honour'd thee;
But ſince thou ſtealſt upon me like a Spie,
And thiefe-like thinkſt that holy caſe ſhall carry thee
Through all my purpoſes, and ſo betray me,
Baſe as you act, thy end be, and I forget thee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What poore evaſions thou buildſt on, to abuſe me?
The goodneſſe of a man nere taught theſe principles.
I come a Spie? durſt any Noble ſpirit
Put on this habit, to become a Traitor?
Even in an Enemy ſhew me this antipathy
Where there is Chriſtian faith, and this not reverenced:
I come a Spie? no Roderigo, no,
A hater of thy perſon, a maligner?
So far from that, I brought no malice with me,
But rather when I meet thee, teares to ſoften thee;
When I put on this habit, I put off
All fires, all angers, all thoſe ſtarts of youth
That clapt too ranke a biaſſe to my being,
And drew me from the right marke all ſhould aime at;
In ſtead of ſtubborne ſteele, I put on prayers;
For raſh and haſty heats, a ſweet repentance:
Long weary ſteps, and vows, for my vain-glories.
O Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If thy tongue could ſave thee,
Prating be thy baile, thou haſt a rare benefit.
Souldiers, come out, and bring a halter with ye;
Ile forgive your holy habit ſir, but Ile hang you.

sp.speaker: 1 Out-l.
sp.l: Wherefore this halter Captaine?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: For this traytor.
Go, put it on him, and then tie him up:
Do you want a Band ſir? this is a courſe wearing,
Twill fit but ſcurvily upon this collar;
But patience is as good as a French Pickadell.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What's his fault, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Tis my will he periſh,
And thats his fault.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A Captaine of good government.
Come Souldiers, come, ye are roughly bred, and bloody,
Shew your obedience, and the joy ye take
In executing impious commands;
Ye have a Captaine ſeales your liberall pardons,
Be no more Chriſtians, put religion by,
Twill make ye cowards: feele no tenderneſſe,
Nor let a thing call'd conſcience trouble ye;
Alaſſe, twill breed delay. Beare no reſpect
To what I ſeem: were I a Saint indeed,
Why ſhould that ſtagger ye? you know not holineſſe:
To be excellent in evill, is your goodneſſe;
And be ſo, twill become ye: have no hearts,
For feare you ſhould repent: that will be dangerous:
For if there be a knocking there, a pricking,
And that pulſe beate backe to your conſiderations,
How ye have laid a ſtiffe hand on Religion—

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Truſſe him I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And violated faith,

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: heare him not prate.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why, what a thing will this be?
What ſtrange confuſion then will breed among ye?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Will none of ye obey?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What devils vex ye?
The feares ye live in and the hourely dangers
Will be delights to theſe: thoſe have their ends,
But theſe outlive all time, and all repentance:
And if it creep into your conſcience once,
Be ſure ye locke that cloſe.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why ſtand ye gazing?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Farewell ſleep, peace, all that are humane comforts,
Better ye had been Trees, or Stones, and happier;
For thoſe die here, and ſeeke no further being,
Nor hopes, nor puniſhments.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Rots take ye Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: What would you have us do?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Diſpatch the prater.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And have religious blood hang on our conſciences?
We are bad enough already: ſins enough
To make our graves even loath us.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: No man love me?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Although I be a thiefe, I am no hangman;
They are two mens trades, and let another execute.
Lay violent hands on holy things?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Baſe Cowards,
Put to your powers, ye Raſcals, I command ye.
Holy, or unholy, if I ſay it,
Ile have it done.

sp.speaker: 1 Out-l.
sp.l: If I do't, let me ſtarve for't.
Or I.
Or I: we will obey things handſome,
And bad enough, and over doe obedience:
But to be made ſuch inſtruments of miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I have done as many villanies as another,
And with as little reluctation,
Let me come cleare of theſe, and wipe that ſcore off.
Put me upon a felt and known perdition?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Have ye conſpir'd, ye ſlaves?

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: How vildly this ſhowes,
In one that would command another temper,
And beare no bound in's own?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Am I thus jaded?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is it my life thou long'ſt for Roderigo?
And can no ſacrifice appeaſe thy malice,
But my blood ſpilt? doe it thy ſelfe, diſpatch it;
And as thou takſt the whole revenge unto thee,
Take the whole ſin upon thee; and be mighty,
Mighty in evill, as thou art in anger:
And let not theſe poore wretches houle for thy ſake.
Thoſe things that in thine owne glaſſe ſeeme moſt monſtrous,
Wouldſt thou abuſe their weak ſights with, for amiable?
Is it, thou thinkſt to feare me with thy terrors,
And into weake condition draw my vertue?
If I were now to learn to die I would ſue to thee:
Or did I feare death, then I would make thee glorious.
But knowing what, and how far I can ſuffer;
And all my whole life being but deaths preface,
My ſleep but at next doore.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Are ye ſo valiant?
Ile make ye feele: Ile make ye know, and feele too;
And Raſcals, you ſhall tremble. Keepe him here,
And keep him ſafe too: if he ſcape your guards—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Feare not, I will not.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: As I live, ye die for't;
I will not be thus baffled. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What a divel have ye done, Pilgrim? or what miſchief
Have you conſpir'd, that he ſhould rage and rave thus?
Have you kild his father, or his mother? or ſtrangled any of his kindred?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Has he no ſiſters? have you not been bouncing
About their belly pieces?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Why ſhould that be dangerous
Or any way deſerve death? is it not naturall?
Bar us the Chriſtian liberty of women,
And build us up with bricK, take away our free-ſtone.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: Becauſe thou art holier then he, upon my conſcience
He dos not envy thee: that's not his quarrell;
For, look you, that might be cōpounded without praiers.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nor that thou ſeemſt an honeſter man: for here
We have no trading with ſuch Tinſell-ſtuffe;
To be an excellent thiefe, is all we aime at.
Wilt thou take a ſpit: and ſtride, and ſee if thou canſt outrun us?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I ſcorn to ſhift his fury, keepe your obedience;
For though your government admit no preſident,
Keep your ſelves carefull in't.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Thou will be hang'd then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I cannot die with fewer faults upon me.

sp.speaker: 2 Out-l.
sp.l: Tis ten to one he wil ſhoot him: for the devil's in him
If he hang him himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He has too proud a nature:
He will compell ſome one.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I am confident.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And ſo are all I thinke.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Be not moleſted,
If I muſt die, let it not trouble you;
It ſtirs not me: It is the end I was born for.
Onely this honeſt office I deſire ye,
(If there be curteſie in men of your breed)
To ſee me buried; not to let his fury
Expoſe my body to the open violence
Of beaſts, and fowles: ſo far I urge humanity.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: He ſhall not deny us that: we'l ſee ye under ground
And give ye a volley of as good cups of Sacke,
For that's our Diſcipline.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He comes againe,
As high in rage as ever; the boy with him.

sp.speaker: 1 Out-l.
sp.l: Will he compell the child?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He is bent to doe it,
And muſt have ſome body.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: If thou lov'ſt me doe it:
Love me, or love me not, I ſay thou ſhalt doe it:
Stare not, nor ſtagger, ſirra; if ye deny me,
Doe you ſee this Rogue?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: What would ye have me doe ſir?
Heavens goodneſſe bleſſe me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Doe? why hang a Raſcall,
That would hang me.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I am a boy, and weake, ſir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou art ſtrong enough to tie him to a Bough,
And turn him off: come, thou ſhalt be my Jewell,
And Ile allow thee horſe, and all thy pleaſures,
And twenty gallant things: Ile teach thee armes too;
Make thee mine heire.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Let me inherit death firſt.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Make me not angry, ſirha.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Which is the man, ſir?
Ile pluck up the beſt heart I can yet.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Feare not,
It is my will: That in the Pilgrimes coate there,
That devill in the Saints skin.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Guard me goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Diſpatch him preſently.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I wait your worſt, ſir.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: will the boy doe it? is the rogue ſo confident?
So young, ſo deep in blood?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He ſhakes, and trembles.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Doſt thou ſeeke more coles ſtill to ſear thy conſci|ence,
Worke ſacred innocence, to be a devill?
Doe it thy ſelfe for ſhame, thou beſt becomſt it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sirha, I ſcorn my finger ſhould be filde with thee;
And yet Ile have it done: this child ſhall ſtrangle thee,
A crying Girle, if ſhe were here ſhould maſter thee.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: How ſhould I ſave him? how my ſelf from violence?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Leave your tongue-valour, & diſpatch your hate, ſir;
The patience of my death, ſhall more torment thee,
(Thou painted honour, thou baſe man made backward)
Then all my life has fear'd thee.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: Gag him, ſirha.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: The Boy looks cheerfully now: ſure he will do it.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He will mall him elſe.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Are ye prepar'd to die, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes boy, and ready; prethee to thy buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Why are ye then ſo angry? ſo perplext, ſir?
Patience wins Heaven, and not the heat of paſſion.
Why doe you rayle?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The boy's a pretty Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I thank ye gentle child, you teach me truely.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You ſeem to feare too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Thou ſeeſt more, then I feel, boy.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You tremble ſure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No ſure boy, tis thy tenderneſſe:
Prethee make haſte, and let that gulph be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Are ye ſo willing to goe to it?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Moſt willing:
I would not borrow from his curteſie
One houre of life, to gaine an age of glory.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And is your reckoning ſtraight ſir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As ſtraight as truth, boy:
I cannot go more joyfully to a wedding.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Then to your prayers: Ile diſpatch ye preſently.
Now guid my tongue, thou bleſſedneſſe.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: A good boy.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: But harke ye ſir, one word; and pray ye reſolve me.
Let me ſpeake privately.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What wouldſt thou have child?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Shall this man die?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why doſt thou make that queſtion?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Pray ye be not angry: if he muſt, Ile doe it.
But muſt he now?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What elſe? who dare reprieve him?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Pray ye thinke againe; and as your injuries
Are great, and full, you ſuffer from this fellow,
Doe not ye purpoſe ſo to ſuit your vengeance?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I doe, and muſt.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You cannot if he die now.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Cannot?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No, cannot: be not vext, you'l finde it.
I have conſidered, and I know it certaine,
Ye ſuffer below him: loſe all your angers.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why my beſt boy?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I love, and tender ye,
I would not tell ye elſe. Is that revenge,
To ſleight your cauſe, and Saint your enemy,
Clap the Doves wings of downy peace unto him,
And let him ſoare to Heaven, whilſt you are ſighing?
Is this revenge?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I would have him die.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Prepar'd thus?
The bleſſing of a father never reach'd it:
His contemplation now ſcornes ye, contemnes ye,
And all the tortors ye can uſe. Let him die thus;
And theſe that know and love revenge will laugh at ye:
Here lies the honour of a wel-bred anger,
To make his enemy ſhake and tremble under him;
Doubt: nay, almoſt deſpaire, and then confound him.
This man ye rocke aſleep, and all your rages
Are Requiems to his parting ſoule, meere Anthems.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Indeed he is ſtrongly built.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You cannot ſhake him;
And the more waight ye put on his foundation,
Now as he ſtands, ye fixe him ſtill the ſtronger;
If ye love him, honour him, would heape upon him
Friendſhips and benefits beyond example,
Hope him a Star in Heaven, and there would ſtick him,
Now take his life.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I had rather take mine own, Boy.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ile eaſe him preſently.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Stay, be not haſty.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Bleſſe my tongue ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What has the boy done to him?
How dull, and ſtill he lookes?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You are a wiſe man.
And long have buckled with the worlds extremities,
A valiant man, and no doubt know both fortunes,
And would ye work your Maſter-peece thus madly,
Take the bare name of honour, that will pitty ye
When the world knows ye have prey'd on a poor Pil|grim?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The Boy has ſtaggard me: what would'ſt thou have me?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Have ye? do you not feel Sir? do's it not ſtir ye?
Doe you aske a child? I would have ye do moſt bravely,
Becauſe I moſt affect ye: like your ſelfe Sir,
Scorn him, and let him goe; ſeem to contemne him,
And now ye have made him ſhake, ſeale him his pardon,
When he appears a ſubject fit for Anger,
And fit for you, his pious Armour off,
His hopes no higher then your ſword may reach at
Then ſtrike, and then ye know revenge; then take it.
I hope I have turn'd his mind.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Let the foole goe there,
I ſcorn to let looſe ſo baſe an anger
May light on thee: See me no more, but quit me;
And when we meet again.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I'le thank ye Captaine. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Why this was like your ſelfe: but which way goes he?
Shall we ne're happy meet?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I am drowſie; Boy,
Goe with me, and diſcourſe: I like thy company
O Child! I love thy Tongue.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I ſhall waite on ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The Boy has don't: a Plaguey witty Raſcall.
And I ſhall love him terribly.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: 'Twas he moſt certaine,
For if ye marke, how earneſt he was with him,
And how he labour'd him.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A cutting villaine,
But a good Rogue; This Boy will make's all honeſt.

sp.speaker: 1. Outl.
sp.l: I ſcarce beleeve that: but I like the Boy well
Come, let's to Supper; then upon our watches.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This Pilgrim ſcap'd a joyfull one.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Let's Drink round,
To the Boyes health, and then about our buſineſſe.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Roderigo, Iaques, Loper, and three Out-Lawes.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: None of you know her?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Alas Sir, we never ſaw her:
Nor ever heard of her, but from your report.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: No happy eye?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I doe not think 'tis ſhe, Sir,
Me thinks a woman dares not.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou ſpeak'ſt poorely,
What dares not woman, when ſhe is provok'd?
Or what ſeemes dangerous to Love, or fury?
That it is ſhe, this has confirm'd me certain,
Theſe Jewels here, a part of which I ſent her,
And though unwilling, yet her Father wrought her
To take, and weare.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A wench, and we not know it?
And among us? where were our underſtandings?
I could have gheſſ'd unhappily: have had ſome feeling
In ſuch a matter: Here are as pretty fellowes,
At the diſcovery of ſuch a Jigambob:
A handſome wench too? ſure we have loſt our faculties,
We have no motions: what ſhould ſhe doe here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That's it that troubles me: O that baſe Raſcall!
There lies the miſery: how cunningly ſhe quit him,
And how ſhe urg'd? had ye been conſtant to me,
I ne're had ſuffer'd this.

sp.speaker: 1. Outl.
sp.l: Ye might have hang'd him:
And would he had been hang'd, that's all we care for't:
So our hands had not don't.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: She is gone again too,
And what care have ye for that? gone, and contemn'd me;
Maſter'd my will, and power, and now laughs at me.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The devill that brought her hither, Sir I thinke
Has carryed her back again inviſible,
For we ne're knew, nor heard of her departure.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: No living thing came this night through our watches
She went with you:

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Was by me till I ſlept,
But when I wak'd, and call'd: O my dull pate here,
If I had open'd this when it was given me,
This Roguy Box. Enter Al|phonſo, and 2 Outlaw.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We could but give it ye.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: Pilgrime? a Pox O Pilgrimes there the game goes,
There's all my fortune fled; I know it, I feele it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Bring me unto thy Captain: where's thy Captain?
I am founder'd, melted, ſome fairy thing or other
Has led me dauncing; the devill has haunted me
Ith' likeneſſe of a voyce: give me thy Captaine.

sp.speaker: 2. Outl.
sp.l: He's here Sir, there he ſtands.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How do'ſt thou Captain?
I have been fool'd and jaded, made a dogge bolt.
My daughters runne away: I have been haunted too,
I have loſt my horſe; I am hungry, & out of my wits alſo.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Come in; I'le tell you what I know: ſtrange things
And take your eaſe; I'le follow her recovery,
Theſe ſhall be yours the whil'ſt, and do ye ſervice.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let me have drinke enough: I am almoſt choak'd too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You ſhall have any thing; what think you now, Souldiers?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I think a woman, is a woman that's any thing.
The next we take, we'l ſearch a little neerer,
We'l not be boyed again with a paire of breeches. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: He's gone in here: This is Roderigo's quarter,
And i'le be with him ſoone: I'le ſtartle him,
A little better then I have done: All this long night againe,
I have led him out o'th way, to try his patience,
And made him ſweare, and curſe; and pray, and ſweare
And cry for anger; I made him leave his horſe too,
Where he can never find him more; whiſtled to him,
And then he would run through thick & thin, to reach me,
And down in this ditch; up again, and ſhake him,
And ſwear ſome certaine bleſſings; then into that buſh
Pop goes his pate, and all his face is comb'd over,
And I ſit laughing: a hundred tricks, I have ſerv'd him:
And I will double em, before I leave him;
I'le teach his anger to diſpute with women,
But all this time, I cannot meet my Miſtreſſe,
I cannot come to comfort her; that grieves me,
For ſure ſhe is much afflicted: till I doe,
I'le haunt thy Ghoſt Alphonſo; I'le keep thee waking,
Yes, I muſt get a Drum: I am villanous weary,
And yet i'le trot about theſe villages
Till I have got my will, and then have at ye.
I'le make your anger drop out at your elbowes ere I leave ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange, in all the circuit we have ridden,
We cannot croſſe her: no way light upon her:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I doe not think ſhe is gone thus far, or this way,
For certain if ſhe had, we ſhould have reach'd her
Made ſome diſcovery: heard ſome news; we have ſeen, nothing.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nor paſſe by any body that could promiſe any thing.
She is certainly diſguiſ'd, her modeſty
Durſt never venture elſe.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Let her take any ſhape,
And let me ſee it once, I can diſtinguiſh it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So ſhould I think too: has not her father found her?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: No, i'le be hang'd then; he has no patience
Unleſſe ſhe light in's teeth, to looke about him.
He gueſſes now, and chafes and frets like Tinſell.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let him goe on, he cannot live without it.
But keep her from him, heaven: where are we Curi?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: In a wood I think, hang me if I know elſe.
And yet I have ridden all theſe Coaſts, at all houres,
And had and aime.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I would we had a guid,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: And if I be not much awry Seberto,
Not far off ſhould be Rodorigo's quarter,
For in this Faſtwes if I be not cozen'd,
He and his Out-laws live.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This is the place then Enter Aliuda.
We appointed him to meet in.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Yes, I thinke ſo:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Would we could meet ſome living thing: what's that there?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A Boy, I think, ſtay; why may not he direct us.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I am hungry, and I am weary, and I cannot find him.
Keep my wits heaven, I feele 'em wavering,
O God my head.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Boy, doſt thou heare, thou ſtripling?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Now they will teare me, torture me, now Roderigo
Will hang him without mercy; ha:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Come hither.
A very pretty Boy: what place is this, child?
And whether doſt thou travell? how he ſtares!
Some ſtubborn Maſter has abu'd the Boy,
And beaten him: how he complaines! whether goeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I goe to Segonia Sir, to my ſick Mother,
I have been taken here by drunken theeves,
And (O my bones;) I have been beaten Sir.
Miſ-us'd, & rob'd: extreamly beaten Gentlemen,
O God, my ſide!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What beaſts would uſe a Boy thus?
Look up, and be of good cheer:

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O, I cannot.
My back, my back, my back.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: What theeves?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I know not.
But they call the Captaine Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Look ye,
I know we were there abouts;

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Do'ſt thou want any thing?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Nothing but eaſe, but eaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: There's ſome mony,
And get thee to thy Mother.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I thank ye Gentlemen:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This was extreamely foule, to vex a Child thus.
Come, let's along, we cannot looſe our way now. Ex.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Though ye are honeſt men, I feare your fingers,
And glad I am got off; O how I tremble!
Send me but once within his armes dear Fortune,
And then come all the world: what ſhall I do now?
'Tis almoſt night again, and where to lodge me, Enter Iuletta.
Or get me meat, or any thing, I know not.
Theſe wild woods, and the fancies I have in me,
Will run me mad.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Boy, Boy:

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: More ſet to take me?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Do'ſt thou heare Boy; thou pointer.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: 'Tis a Boy too,
A Lacky Boy: I need not feare his feirceneſſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Canst thou beat a Drum?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: A Drum?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This thing, a drum here.
Didſt thou never ſee a Drum: Canſt thou make this grumble?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Iulettas face, and tongue; Is ſhe run mad too?
Here may be double craft: I have no skill in't.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I'le give thee a Royall but to goe along with me.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I care not for thy Royall, I have other buſineſſe,
Drum to thy ſelfe, and daunce to it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Sirha, Sirha.
Thou ſcurvy Sitha; thou ſnotty-nos'd ſcab, do'ſt thou heare me?
If I lay downe my Drum. Enter Rodorigo, and two Outlaw.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Here comes more Company,
I feare a plot, heaven ſend me fairely from it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Baſto; who's here?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Captain, do you need me Father?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: No not a foot: give me the gowne: the ſword now.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This is the devill theef, and if he take me,
Woe be to my Gally-gaskins.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Certaine Sir,
She will take her patches of, and change her habit.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Let her do what ſhe pleaſe: No, no Alinda
You cannot cozen me againe in a Boyes figure,
Nor hide the beauty of that face in patches,
But I ſhall know it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A Boy his face in patches?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nor ſhall your tongue againe bewitch mine Anger,
If ſhe be found ith' woods, ſend me word preſently,
And i'le returne; ſhe cannot be farre gone yet,
If ſhe be not, expect me, when ye ſee me,
Uſe all your ſervice to my friend Alphonſo,
And have a care to your buſineſſe: farewell,
No more, farewell. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am heartily glad thou art gone yet.
This Boy in patches, was the Boy came by me,
The very ſame, how haſtily it ſhifted?
What a mopp'-eyed aſſe was I, I could not know her,
This muſt be ſhe, this is ſhe, now I remember her,
How loth ſhe was to talk too, how ſhe fear'd me?
I could now piſſe mine eyes out for meer anger:
I'le follow her, but who ſhall vex her father then?
One flurt at him, and then I am for the voyage,
If I can croſſe the Captain too: Come Tabor. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Are they all ſet?

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: All, and each quarter quiet.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Is the old man aſleep?

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: An houre agoe Sir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: We muſt be very carefull in his abſence,
And very watchfull.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: It concerns us neerely,
He will not be long from us.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: No, he cannot,

sp.speaker: 1 Out-l.
sp.l: A little heate of love, which he muſt wander out. Drum a far off.
And then again: harke.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: 1 Out-l.
sp.l: Tis not the wind ſure:
That's ſtill and calme▪ no noyſe, nor flux of waters.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I heare a Drum, I thinke.

sp.speaker: 1 Out-l.
sp.l: That that;
It beats againe now.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Now it comes neerer: ſure we are ſurprized, ſir;
Some from the Kings command: we are loſt, we are
dead all.

sp.speaker: 1 Out-l.
sp.l: Hark, hark, a charge now: my Captaine has betray'd us.
And left us to this ruine, run away from us.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Another beates o'that ſide.

sp.speaker: 2 Out-l.
sp.l: Fly, flie, Jaques,
We are taken in a toyle: ſnapt in a pitfall;
Methinks I feele a Sword already ſhave me.

sp.speaker: 3 Out-l
sp.l: A thouſand horſe and foot, a thouſand pioners,
If we get underground, to fetch us out againe;
And every one an Axe to cut the woods downe.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This is the diſmalſt night— Exit.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Where's my nag now?
And what make I here to be hang'd? What devill
brought me into this danger? Is there nere a hole?
That I may creep in deep enough, and the quickly?
Nere an old ditch to choke in? I ſhall be taken
For their Commander now, their Generall,
And have a commanding Gallows ſet up for me
As high as a May-pole; and naſty Songs made on me,
Be printed with a Pint-pot and a dagger.
They are all kill'd by this time: Can I pray?
Let me ſee that firſt: I have too much feare to be faithfull.
Where's all my State now? I muſt go hunt for daughters;
Daughters, and damſels of the Lake, damned daughters.
A hundred Crownes for a good tod of Hay,
Or a fine hollow Tree, that would containe me;
I heare 'em comming: I feele the nooze about me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why do you fear, and fly? here are no Souldiers;
None from the King to vex ye.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: The Drum, the Drum, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I never ſaw ſuch Pigeon-hearted people:
What Drum? what danger? who's that that ſhakes behind there:
Mercy upon me ſir, why are ye fear'd thus?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Are we all kill'd, no mercy to be hoped for?
Am I not ſhot do you think?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You are ſtrangely frighted,
Shot with a fiddle ſtick: who's here to ſhoot ye?
A Drum we ſaw indeed, a boy was beating it,
And hunting Squirrels by Moon-light.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nothing elſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Not any thing: no other perſon ſtirring.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: O that I had that boy: this is that Devill,
That fairy rogue, that haunted me laſt night;
H'as ſleeves like Dragons wings.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A little Foot-boy.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Come, let's go in, and let me get my clothes on;
If ere I ſtay here more to be thus martyr'd -
Did ye not meet the wench?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No ſure, we met her not.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: She has been here in boyes apparrell, Gentlemen,
A gallant thing, and famous for a Gentlewoman,
And all her face patcht over for diſcovery:
A pilgrime too, and thereby hangs a circumſtance,
Tha ſhe hath playd her maſter-prize, a rare one.
I came too ſhort.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Such a young boy we met ſir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: In a gray hat.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: The ſame: his face all patcht too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Twas ſhe, a rot run with her; ſhe: that ranck ſhe;
Walk in, Ile tell ye all: and then we'l part again,
But get ſome ſtore of Wine: this fright ſits here yet. Ex.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What a fright I have put 'em in; what a brave hurry.
If this doe bolt him, Ile be with him againe
With a new part, was never play'd; Ile ferk him.
As he hunts her, ſo ile hunt him: Ile claw him.
Now will I ſee if I can croſſe her footing:
Yet ſtill ile watch his water, he ſhall pay for't;
And when he thinks moſt malice, and meanes worſe,
Ile make him know the Mare's the better Horſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Ye are a ſtranger ſir, and for humanity,
Being come within our walls, I would ſhew you ſomething.
Ye have ſeen the Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes ſir, tis aſtrong one,
And well maintain'd.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why are you ſtill thus ſad, ſir?
How doe ye like the walkes?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They are very pleaſant;
Your Town ſtands coole and ſweet.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But that I would not
Affect you with more ſadneſſe, I could ſhew ye
A place worth view.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Showes ſeldome alter me ſir;
Pray ye ſpeake it, and then ſhew it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Tis a houſe here
Where people of all ſorts, that have been viſited
With lunacies and follies waite their cures,
Their's fancies of a thouſand ſtamps and faſhions,
Like flies in ſeverall ſhapes buze round about ye,
And twice as many geſtures; ſome of pitty,
That it would make ye melt to ſee their paſſions:
And ſome as light againe, that would content ye.
But I ſee ſir, your temper is too modeſt,
Too much inclin'd to contemplation,
To meet with theſe?

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: You could not pleaſe me better;
And I beſeech you ſir, doe me the honour
To let me waite upon ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Since ye are willing,
To me it ſhall be a pleaſure to conduct ye.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I never had ſuch a mind yet to ſee miſery. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena ſexta.

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: Carry mad Beſse ſome meat, ſhe rores like Thunder;
And tie the Parſon ſhort, the Moone's ith full,
H'as a thouſand Pigs in's braines: Who lookes to the Prentize?
Keep him from women, he thinks h'as loſt his Miſtris,
And talke of no ſilke ſtuffes, 'twill runne him horn mad.

sp.speaker: 2 Keep.
sp.l: The Juſtice keeps ſuch a ſtirre yonder with his Charges,
And ſuch a coyle with warrants,

sp.speaker: 1 K.
sp.l: Take away his Statutes;
The divell has poſſeſt him in the likeneſſe
Of penall Lawes: keep him from Aquavite,
For if that ſpirit creep into his corum,
He will commit us all: how is it with the Scholler?

sp.speaker: 2 K.
sp.l: For any thing I ſee, he's in his right wits.

sp.speaker: 1 K.
sp.l: Thou art an aſſe; in's right wits, goodman coxcomb?
As though any man durſt be in's right wits, and be here.
It is as much as we dare be that keep 'em.

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Give me ſome drink.

sp.speaker: 1 K.
sp.l: O, there's the Engliſh man.

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Fill me a thouſand pots, and froth 'em, froth 'em.
Down o' your knees, ye rogues, and pledge me roundly;
One, two, three, and foure; we ſhall be an merry within this houre.
To the great Turke.

sp.speaker: 1 K.
sp.l: Peace, peace, thou Heathen drunkard;
Theſe Engliſh are ſo Malt-mad, there's no medling with 'em;
When they have a fruitfull yeere of Barly there,
All the whole Iſland's thus.

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: A Snuff, a ſnuff, a ſnuff.
A lewd notorious ſnuff: giv't him againe, boy.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: God-ye-good even, Goffer.

sp.speaker: 2 K.
sp.l: Who let the Foole looſe?

sp.speaker: 1 K.
sp.l: If any of the mad-men take her, ſhe is pepper'd,
They'l bounce her loynes.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Will ye walke into the cole houſe?

sp.speaker: 1●p.
sp.l: She is as leacherous too as a ſhe-ferret.

sp.speaker: 2 K.
sp.l: Who a vengeance looks to her? go in Kate,
Ile give thee a fine Apple.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Will ye buſſe me?
And tickle me, and make me laugh?

sp.speaker: 1 K.
sp.l: Ile whip ye.

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Foole, foole, come up to me foole.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Are ye peeping?

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Ile get thee with five fooles.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: O fine, O dainty.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: And thou ſhalt lie in in a horſe-cloth, like a Lady

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: And ſhall I have a Coach?

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Drawn with foure Turkeys,
And they ſhall tread thee too.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: We ſhall have egges then;
And ſhall I ſit upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: I, I, and they ſhall be all addle,
And make an admirable Tanzey for the divell.
Come come away, I am taken with thy love foole,
And will mightily belabour thee.

sp.speaker: 1 K.
sp.l: How the foole bridles? how ſhe twitters at him?
Theſe Engliſhmen would ſtagger a wiſe-woman.
If we ſhould ſuffer her to have her will now,
We ſhould have all the women in Spaine at mad as ſhe here,

sp.speaker: 2 K.
sp.p: They would ſtrive who ſhould be moſt fool: away with her.

div.stage: Enter Maſter, three Gentlemen, a mad Scholler, and Pedro.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Pray ye ſtay a little: lets heare him ſing, h'as a fine breaſt.

sp.speaker: 1 K.
sp.l: Here comes my Maſter, to the ſpit ye whore,
And ſtir no more abroad, but tend your buſineſſe;
Your ſhall have no more ſops ith' pan elſe, nor no porrige:
Beſides, Ile whip your breech.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Ile goe in preſently.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Ile aſſure ye ſir, the Cardinal's angry with ye
For keeping this young man.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I am heartily ſorry.
If ye allow him ſound, pray ye take him with ye.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: This is the place, and now obſerve their humors:

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: We can find nothing in him light, nor tainted;
No ſtartings, nor no rubs, in all his anſwers,
In all his Letters nothing but diſcretion,
Learning, and handſome ſtile.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Be not deceived ſir,
Marke but his looke.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: His griefe, and his impriſonment
May ſtamp that there.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Pray talke with him again then.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: That will be needleſſe, we have tride him long enough,
And if he had a taint we ſhould have met with't.
Yet to diſcharge your care —

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A ſober youth:
Pity ſo heavy a croſſe ſhould light upon him.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: You finde no ſickneſſe?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: None ſir, I thank Heaven,
Nor nothing that diverts my underſtanding.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Doe you ſleep a nights?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: As ſound, and ſweet, as any man:

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Have ye no fearfull dreams?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Sometimes, as all have
That go to bed with raw and windy ſtomacks;
Elſe, I am all one piece.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Is there no unkindneſſe
You have conceiv'd from any friend or parent?
Or ſcorne from what ye lov'd?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: No, truely ſir:
I never yet was maſter of a faith
So poore, and weake, to doubt my friend or kindred,
And what love is, unleſſe it lie in learning
I thinke I am ignorant.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: This man is perfect,
A civiller diſcourſer I nere talk'd with.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: You'l finde it otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I muſt tell ye true ſir,
I thinke ye keep him here to teach him madneſſe.
Here's his diſcharge from my Lord Cardinall;
And come ſir, goe with us.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: I am bound unto ye,
And farewell Maſter.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Farewell Stephano,
Alas poore man.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: What flaws, and whirles of weather,
Or rather ſtorms have been aloft theſe three daies;
How darke, and hot, and full of mutiny!
And ſtill grows lowder.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: It has been ſtubborn weather.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Strange work at Sea, I fear me there's old tumbling.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Bleſſe my old unkles Barke, I have a venture.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: And I more then I would wiſh to loſe.

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Doe you feare?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Ha! how he lookes?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Nay, marke him better Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Mercy upon me: how his eyes are altered?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Now tell me how ye like him: whether now
He be that perfect man ye credited?

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Doe's the Sea ſtaggger ye?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Now ye have hit the nick.

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Doe ye feare the billowes?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: What ailes him? who has ſtir'd him?

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Be not ſhaken,
Nor let the ſinging of the ſtorm ſhoot through ye,
Let it blow on, blow on: let the clouds wraſtle,
And let the vapours of the earth turn mutinous,
The Sea in hideous niountaines riſe and tumble
Upon a Dolphins back, Ile make all tremble,
For I am Neptune.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Now what think ye of him?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: A las poore man.

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Your Barke ſhall plough through all,
And not a Surge ſo ſaucy to diſturbe her.
Ile ſee her ſafe, my power ſhall ſaile before her.

body.l: Down ye angry waters all,
Ye loud whiſtling whirlwinds fall;
Down ye proud Waves, ye ſtormes ceaſe;
I command ye, be at peace.
Fright not with your churliſh Notes,
Nor bruiſe the Keele of Bark that flotes:
No devouring Fiſh come nigh,
Nor Monſter in my Empery,
Once ſhew his head, or terror bring;
But let the weary Saylor ſing:
Amphitrite with white armes
Srike my Lute, Ile ſing Charmes.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: He muſt have Muſicke now: I muſt obſerve him.
His fit will grow to full elſe. Muſick, Song.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I muſt pitty him.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Now he will in himſelfe moſt quietly,
And clean forget all, as he had done nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: We are ſorry, ſir: and we have ſeen a wonder;
From this houre we'l believe, and ſo we'l leave ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This was a ſtrange fit.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Did ye marke him ſir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He might have cozen'd me with his behaviour.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Many have ſworn him right, and I have thought ſo:
Yet on a ſudden, from ſome word, or other,
When no man could expect a ſit, he has flown out:
I dare not give him will.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Pray Heaven recover him.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Muſt I come in too?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: No, my pretty Lad;
Keep in thy chamber Boy: 'ſhalt have thy ſupper.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I pray ye what is he ſir?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: A ſtrange boy, that laſt night
Was found i'th' Town, a little craz'd, diſtracted,
And ſo ſent hither.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How the pretty knave looks,
And playes, and peepes upon me! ſure ſuch eyes
I have ſeen, and lov'd: what fair hands? certainly—

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Good ſir, you'l make him worſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I pray believe not.
Alas, why ſhould I hurt him? how he ſmiles?
The very ſhape, and ſweetneſſe of Alinda:
Let me look once againe: were it in ſuch clothes
As when I ſaw her laſt; this muſt be ſhe.
How tenderly it ſtroakes me?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Pray ye be mild ſir;
I muſt attend elſewhere. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Pray ye be ſecure ſir,
What would ye ſay? how my heart beates and trembles?
He holds me hard by th' hand; O my life, her fleſh too!
I know not what to think: her teares, her true ones;
Pure orient teares: Hark, doe you know me little one?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O Pedro Pedro!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O my ſoule!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What fit's this?
The Pilgrimes off the hooks too.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Let me hold thee,
And now come all the world, and all that hate me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Be wiſe, and not diſcovered: O how I love ye!
How doe ye now?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I have been miſerable;
But your moſt vertuous eyes have cur'd me, Pedro:
Pray ye thinke it no immodeſty, I kiſſe ye,
My head's wild ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Be not ſo full of paſſion,
Nor do not hang ſo greedily upon me;
Twill be ill taken.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Are ye weary of me?
I will hang here eternally, kiſſe ever,
And weep away for joy.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I told ye ſir,
What ye would doe: for ſhame doe not afflict him;
You have drawn his fit upon him fearfully:
Either depart, and preſently; Ile force ye elſe.
Who waits within?

div.stage: Enter two Keepers to fetch 'em off.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Alas good ſir.
This is the way never to hope recovery.
Stay but one minute more, Ile complaine to the Governour.
Bring in the boy: doe you ſee how he ſwels, and teares himſelfe?
Is this your cure? Be gon; if the boy miſcarry
Let me nere find you more, for ile ſo hamper ye —

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You were too blame: too raſh.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Farewell for ever. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are now within a mile oth' Towne ſir: if my buſineſſe
Would give me leave, I would turne and waite upon ye;
But for ſuch Gentlemen as you enquire of,
Certaine, I ſaw none ſuch: But for the boy ye ſpoke of,
I will not ſay tis he, but ſuch a one;
Juſt of that height.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: In ſuch clothes?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I much miſtake elſe,
Was ſent in th'other night, a little maddiſh,
And where ſuch people waite their cures.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I underſtand ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: There you may quickly know.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I thanke ye ſir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So doe I to: and if there be ſuch a place,
I aske no more; but you ſhall heare more of me.
She may be there, and you may play the tyrant;
Ile ſee what I can doe: I am almoſt foundred
In following him; and yet Ile never leave him,
Ile crawle of all foure firſt; my cauſe is meritorious,
And come what can come.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: All you have told me is certaine;
Complexion, and all elſe.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: It may be ſhe then;
And ile ſo fumble her: Is ſhe growne mad now?
Is her blood ſet ſo high? ile have her madded,
Ile have her worm'd.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Marke but the end, old Maſter,
If thou beeſt not ſicke oth' Bots within theſe five hours,
And kickſt and roar'ſt; Ile make ye fart fire, Signior,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here's one oth' houſe, a foole, an idiot ſir;
May be ſhe is going home; ſhe'l be a guide to ye;
And ſo I kiſſe your hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O now I am loſt, loſt, loſt, Lord, how I tremble!
My father, arm'd in all his hates and angers;
This is more miſery then I have ſcap'd yet.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Foole, foole.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: He knows me not; will ye give me two-pence?
And gaffer, here's a Crow-flower, and a Dazie;
I have ſome pie in my pocket too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: This is an arrant foole,
An ignorant thing.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Believe ſo, and I am happy.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Doſt thou dwell in Sigonia, foole?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No no, I dwell in Heaven.
And I have a fine little houſe, made of Marmalad.
And I am a lone woman, and I ſpin for Saint Peter;
I have a hundred little children, and they ſing Pſalmes with me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Tis pity this pretty thing ſhould want underſtanding.
But why doe I ſtand talking with a coxcombe?
If I doe finde her, if I light upon her,
Ile ſay no more. Is this the way to th' Town, foole?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You muſt goe over the top of that high ſteeple, Gaffer.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: A plague o' your fooles face.
