sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, take her counſell.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And then you ſhall come to a River twenty mile over,
And twenty mile & ten: and then you muſt pray, Gaffer;
And ſtill you muſt pray, and pray.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pray Heaven deliver me
From ſuch an aſſe, as thou art.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Amen, ſweet Gaffer.
And fling a ſop of Suger-cake into it;
And then you muſt leap in naked.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would he would believe her.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And ſink ſeven daies together; can ye ſinck gaffer?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Yes coxcombe, yes; prethee farewell: a pox on thee.
A plague o' that foole too, that ſet me upon thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And then Ile bring you a ſup of Milke ſhal ſarve ye:
I am going to get Apples.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Go to th' devill:
Was ever man tormented with a puppy thus?
Thou tell me news? thou be a guide?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And then Nunkle —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Prethee keepe on thy way (good Naunt) I could rayle now
Theſe ten houres at mine owne improvidence:
Get Apples, and he choak'd: farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Farewell Nuncle.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I rejoyce in any thing that vexes him;
And I ſhall love this foole extreamly for't:
Could I but ſee my Miſtris now, to tell her
How I have truely, honeſtly wrought for her,
How I have worne my ſelfe away, to ſerve her.
Foole, there's a Royall for the ſport thou mad'ſt me,
In croſſing that old foole, that parted from thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Thou art honeſt ſure; but yet thou muſt not ſee me:
I thanke ye little Gentleman: Heaven bleſſe ye
And ile pray for ye too: pray ye keep this Nutmeg,
Twas ſent me from the Lady of the Mountaine.
A golden Lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How prettily it prattles.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Tis very good to rub your underſtanding:
And ſo good night: the Moone's up.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: Pretty innocent.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Now fortune, if thou dar'ſt do good, protect me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ile follow him to yond Towne: he ſhall not ſcape me:
Stay, I muſt counterfeit a Letter by the way firſt,
And one that muſt carry ſome credit with it: I am wide elſe,
And all this to no purpoſe that I ayme at.
A Letter muſt be had, and neatly handled:
And then if Goodwife fortune doe not faile me,
Have at his skirts: I ſhall worſe anger him
Then ever I have done, and worſe torment him.
It do's me good to thinke how I ſhall conjure him.
And crucifie his crabbedneſſe: he's my Maſter,
But that's all one: Ile lay that on the left hand.
He would now perſecute my harmleſſe Miſtris,
A fault without forgiveneſſe, as I take it;
And under that bold banner flies my vengeance,
A meritorious war, and ſo Ile make it.
I'th' name of Innocence, what's this the foole gave me?
She ſaid twas good to rub my underſtanding.
What ſtrange concealment? Bread or Cheeſe, or a Cheſnut?
Ha! tis a Ring: a pretty Ring, a right one:
A ring I know too! the very ſame Ring:
O admirable Blockhead! O baſe eyes!
A Ring my Miſtris tooke from me, and wore it;
I know it by the Poſie: Prick me, and heale me.
None could deliver this, but ſhe her ſelfe too:
Am I twice ſand-blind? twice ſo neer the bleſſing
I would arive at? and block-like never know it?
I am veng'ance angry, but that ſhal light on thee,
And heavily, and quickly, I pronounce it:
There are ſo many croſſe waies, there's no following her:
And yet I muſt not now: I hope ſhe is right ſtill,
For all her outward ſhew, for ſure ſhe knew me;
And in that hope, ſome few houres Ile forget her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: She is not to be recovered, which I vex at;
And he beyond my veng'ance, which torments me:
O! I am fool'd and ſleighted, made a Raſcall;
My hopes are flatterd, as my preſent fortunes:
Why ſhould I wander thus and play the coxcomes?
Tire out my peace and pleaſure for a Girle?
A Girle that ſcorns me too? a thing that hates me?
And conſidered at the beſt, is but a ſhort breakfaſt
For a hot appetite: why ſhould I walke, and walke thus,
And fret my ſelfe, and travell like a Carrier,
And peep, and watch? want Meat, and Wine, to cheriſh me,
When thouſand women may be had, ten thouſand,
And thank me too, and I ſit ſtill: well, trim Beauty
And Chaſtity, and all that ſeem to ruin me,
Let me not take ye; let me not come neer ye,
For Ile ſo trim ye: Ile ſo buſſell with ye;
Tis not the name of Virgin ſhall redeem ye,
Ile change that property: nor teares, nor angers:
I beare a hate about me ſcorns thoſe follies.
To finde this villaine too, for there's my main prize;
And if he ſnap me then.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Is not that Pedro?
Tis he, tis he: O!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ha? now, now, now,
O now moſt miſerable.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What a' devill art thou?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No end of my miſ-fortunes, Heaven?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What Anticke?
Speake Puppet, ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: That habit to betray me?
Ye holy Saints, can ye ſee this?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: It danceth:
The devill in a fooles Coat, is he turn'd Innocent?
What mops, and mowes it makes: heigh, how it frisketh,
Is't it not a Faiery? or ſome ſmall hobgoblin?
It has a mortall face, and I have a great mind to it,
But if it ſhould prove the devill then.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Come hither.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I think 't will raviſh me,
It is a handſome thing, but horribly Sun-burnt,
What's that it points at?

sp.speaker: Alin,
sp.l: Do'ſt thou ſee that Starre there,
That, juſt above the Sunne;
Prethe goe thither, and light me this Tobacco,
And ſtop it with the hornes o'th' Moone.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The thing's mad,
Abhominably mad, her braines are butter'd,
Goe ſleep, foole, ſleep.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Thou canſt not ſleep ſo ſweetly:
For ſo I can ſay my Prayers, and then ſlumber.

body.l: I am not proud, nor full of wine,
This little Flowre will make me fine:
Cruell in heart, for I ſhall crie,
If I ſee a Sparrow dye:
I am not watchfull to due ill,
Nor glorious to purſue it ſtill:
Nor pittileſſe to thoſe that weepe;
Such as are, bid them goe ſleep.

l.hi: Doe, doe, do, and ſee if they can.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: It ſaid true,
I feele it ſinke into me forcibly.
Sure 'tis a kind of Sibill, ſome mad Prophet.
I feel my wildneſſe bound, and fetter'd in me.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Give me your hand, and i'le tell you what's your fortune.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Here: prethee ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie, fie, fie.
Waſh your hands, and pare your Nailes, and look finely
You ſhall never kiſſe the Kings daughter elſe.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I waſh 'em daily.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: But ſtill you fowle 'em faſter.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This goes neerer.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You'll have two wives.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Two wives?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I two fine gentle-women.
M●ke much of 'em: for they'l ſtick cloſe to you Sir.
And theſe two, in two dayes.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That's a fine Riddle.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: To day you ſhall wed ſorrow,
And repentance will come to morrow.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sure ſhe's inſpired.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I'le ſing ye a fine Song Sir.

l.hi: He called down his merry men all
By one, by two, by three,

sp.l: William would faine have been the firſt,

l.hi: But now the laſt is he.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This the meer Chronicle of my miſ-hap.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I'le bid you good ev'n: for my Boat ſtaies for me yonder,
And I muſt Sup with the Moone to night in the Mediterraneum. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: When fools, and mad-folks ſhall be tutors to me,
And feele my ſores, yet I unſenſible;
Sure it was ſet by Providence upon me
To ſteer my heart right: I am wondrous weary.
My thoughts too, which adde more burthen to me:
I have been ill, and (which is worſe) purſu'd it,
And ſtill runne on: I muſt thinke better, nobler,
And be another thing, or not at all. Enter foure Peſants.
Still I grow heavier, heavier heaven defend me:
I'le lye down, and take reſt: and goodnes guard me.

sp.speaker: Peſ. 1
sp.l: We have ſcap'd to day well: certain, if the Out-laws
Had known we had been ſtirring, we had paid for't,
Plague on 'em, they have rob'd me thrice,
And me five times:
Beſide they made my daughter one of us too
An arrant Drum: O, they are the lewdeſt Raſcals,
The Captaine ſuch a damn'd peece of iniquitie:
But we are farre enough of on 'em, that's the beſt on't,
They cannot heare.
They'le come to me familiarly
And eat up all I have: drinke up my wine too,
And if there be a Servant that content 'em,
Let her keele hold, they'll give her Stowage enough:
We have no Children now, but Theeves, and Outlawes.
The very Brats in their Mothers bellies have their qualities.
They'll ſteale into the world.
Would we had ſome of 'em here,
I, O' that condition we could Maſter 'em,
They are ſturdy knaves.
A devill take their ſturdineſſe,
We can neither keep our wives from 'em, nor our States,
We pay the Rent, and they poſſeſſe the benefit.
What's this lies here? is it drunk, or ſober?
It ſleeps, and ſoundly too.
'Tis an old woman
That keepes ſheepe hereabouts: it turns, and ſtretches.
Do's ſhe keep ſheep with a ſword?
It has a Beard too.
Peace, peace: It is the devill Roderigo,
Peace of all hands, and looke.
'Tis he
Speake ſoftly,
Now we may fit him.
Stay, ſtay: let's be provident.
Kill him, and wake him then.
Let me come to him,
Ev'n one blow at his pate, if ere he wake more.
So, ſo, ſo, lay that by.
I muſt needs kill him.
It ſtands with my reputation
Stand off, I ſay:
And let us ſome way make him ſure; then torture him.
To kill him preſently, has no pleaſure in't.
Has been tormented of us, at leaſt this twelve moneth.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Oh me!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: He comes: he comes.
Has he no Guns about him?
Softly again: no, no: take that hand eaſily,
And tye it faſt there: that to th' other bough there.
Faſt, faſt, and eaſie leaſt he wake.
Have we got ye?
This was a benefit we never aym'd at.
Out with your knives, and let's carve this Cock-theefe,
Daintily carve him.
I would he had been uſed thus
Ten year agoe; we might have thought we had children.
O, that Sir Nicholas now our Prieſt were here.
What a ſweet Homily would he ſay over him,
For ringing all in with his wife in the Bell-frey?
He would ſtand up ſtiffe girt: Now pounce him lightly,
And as he rores, and rages, let's goe deeper:
Come neere: you are dym ey'd: on with your ſpectacles.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O, what torments me thus? what ſlaves, what villaines?
O ſpare me, doe not murther me.
We'll but tickle ye,
You have tickled us at all points.
Where are his Emblemes? Enter Pedro

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: As ye are men, and Chriſtians
Yes we hear ye,
And you ſhall here of us too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Oh no mercy.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What noyſe is this? what rore? I cannot find her,
She is got free again: but where, or which way?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O' villains, beaſts.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Murdring a man, ye raſcals?
Ye inhumane ſlaves, off, off, and leave this cruelty,
Or as I am a Gentleman: do ye brave me?
Then have among ye all, ye ſlaves, ye cowards,
Take up that ſword, and ſtand: ſtay ye baſe raſcals,
Ye cut-throate rogues.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Away, away. Exeunt Peſ.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ye dog-whelps:

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: O' I am how more wretched far, then ever.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A violence to that habit? ha? Roderigo,
What makes he here, thus lad? is it repentance,
Or only a fair ſhew to guid his miſchiefes?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This benefit has made me ſhame to ſee him,
To know him, bluſh?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You are not much hurt?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: No Sir;
All I can call a hurt, ſticks in my conſcience,
That pricks, and tortuers me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Have ye conſiderd
The nature of theſe men, and how they us'd ye?
Was it fair play? did it appear to you handſom?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I dare not ſpeak: or if I do, tis nothing
Can bring me off, or juſtifie me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Was it noble
To be o're-layd with odds, and violence?
Manly, or brave in theſe thus to oppreſſe ye?
Do you bluſh at this, in ſuch as are meer rudenes,
That have ſtopt ſoules, that never knew things gentle?
And dare you glorifie worſe in your ſelf ſir?
Ye uſ'd me with much honour, and I thank ye,
In this I have requited ſome: ye know me:
Come turne not back, ye muſt, and ye ſhall know me;
Had I bin over ſeaſond with baſe anger,
And ſuited all occaſions to my miſchiefes,
Bore no reſpect to Honeſty, Religion,
No faith, no common tie of man, humanity,
Had I had in me, but given reines, and licence
To a tempeſtuous will, as wild as winter,
This day, know Roderigo, I had ſet
As ſmall a price upon thy life, and fortunes,
As thou didſt lately on mine innocence;
But I reſerve thee to a nobler ſervice.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I thank ye, and i'le ſtuddy more to honour ye:
You have the nobler ſoule, I muſt confeſſe it,
And are the greater maſter of your goodnes.
Though it be impoſſible I ſhould now recover,
And my rude will grow handſome in an inſtant,
Yet touching but the purenes of your mettle,
Something ſhall ſhew like gold, at leaſt ſhall gliſter,
That men may hope, although the mine be rugged,
Stony, and hard to work: yet time, and honour
Shall find and bring forth that, that's rich and worthy.

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: I'le trie that: and to 'th purpoſe: ye told me ſir
In noble emulation, ſo I take it;
I'le put your hatred far off, and forget it,
You had a faire deſire to try my valour:
You ſeemd to court me to it; you have found a time,
A weapon in your hand, an equall enemy,
That, as he puts this off, puts of all injuries,
And only now for honors ſake defies ye:
Now, as you are a man, I know you are valiant,
As you are gentle bred, a ſouldier faſhioned.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: His vertue ſtartles me. I dare fight Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And as you have a Miſtris that you honor,
Mark me, a Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A handſome Miſtris,
As you dare hold your ſelf deſerving of her.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Deſerving? what a word was that to fire me?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I could compell ye now without this circumſtance,
But i'le deale free, and fairely, like a Gentleman:
As ye are worthy of the name ye carry,
A daring man.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O that I durſt not ſuffer:
For all I dare do now, implies but pennance.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Now do me noble right.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I'le ſatisfy ye:
But not by th'word: pray ye hear me, and allow me;
I have bin rude: but ſhall I be a monſter,
And teach my ſword to hurt that that preſerved me?
Though I be rough by nature, ſhall my name
Inherit that eternall ſtaine of barbarous?
Give me an enemy, a thing that hates ye,
That never heard of yet, nor felt your goodnes,
That is one main antipathy to ſweetnes;
And ſet me on, you cannot hold me coward:
If I have ever err'd, 'th as in hazard:
The temper of my ſword ſtarts at your vertue,
And will flie off, nay it will weep to light ye;
Things excellently mingled, and of pure nature,
Hold ſacred love, and peace with one another.
See how it turnes.

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: This is a ſtrange converſion:
And can ye faile your Miſtris? can ye grow cold
In ſuch a caſe?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thoſe heats that they adde to us,
(O noble Pedro) let us feele 'em rightly,
And rightly but conſider how they move us.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is not their honour ours?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If they be vertuous;
And then the ſword ads nothing to their luſtre,
But rather cals in queſtion what's not doubted:
If they be not: the beſt ſwords, and beſt valours
Can never fight 'em up to fame again:
No, not a Chriſtian war, and that's held pious.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How bravely now he is tempered? I muſt fight,
And rather make it honorable, then angry,
I would not taske thoſe ſins to me committed.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You cannot ſir: you have caſt thoſe by; decarded 'em,
And in a noble mind, ſo low and looſely
To look back, and collect ſuch lumps, and lick 'em
Into new horrid formes agen.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Still braver.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: To fight, becauſe I dare, were worſe, and weaker
Then if I had a woman in my cauſe, ſir,
And more proclaim'd me foole; yet I muſt confeſſe
I have bin covetous of all occaſions,
And this I have taken upon truſt, for noble,
The more ſhame mine; deviſe a way to fight thus,
That like the wounded aire no blood may iſſue,
Nor where this ſword ſhall enter, no loſt ſpirit,
And ſet me on: I would not ſcar that body,
That vertuous, valiant body, nor deface it
To make the Kingdom mine: if one muſt bleed,
Let me be both the ſacrifice, and altar,
And you the Prieſt: I have deſerv'd to ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The noble Roderigo, now I call ye,
And thus my love ſhall ever count, and hold ye,
I am your ſervant ſir: and now this habit,
Devotion, not diſtruſt ſhall put upon me,
I'le wait upon your fortunes, that's my way now,
And where your grieve, or joy, i'le be a partner.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I thank ye ſir, I ſhall be too proud of ye,
O I could tell ye ſtrange things.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I gheſſe at 'em,
And I could curſe my ſelf, I made 'em ſtranger;
Yet my mind ſayes, you are not far from happines.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: It ſhall be welcome; come, lets keep us thus ſtill,
And be as we appear: Heavens hand may bleſſe us. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Yes ſir, here be ſuch people: but how pleaſing,
They will appear to you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pray let me ſee'm,
I come to that end: pray let me ſee'em all.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: They will confound ye ſir, like bels rung backward
They are nothing but confuſion, and meer noyſes.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: May be I love a noyſe: but hark ye ſir,
Have ye no boyes, handſome yong boyes?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Yes one ſir,
A very handſome boy.

sp.speaker: Alp
sp.l: Long here?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: But two dayes;
A little crazed: but much hope of recovery.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I that boy, let me ſee: may be I know him;
That boy, I ſay: this is the boy he told me of,
And it muſt needs be ſhe: that boy I beſeech ye ſir,
That boy I come to ſee.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: And ye ſhall ſee him:
Or any els, but pray be not too violent.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I know what to do, I warrant ye: I am for all fancies:
I can talk to'em, and diſpute.

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: As madly:
For they be very madde ſir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Let 'em be horne mad.

sp.speaker: 1. Keep.
sp.l: We have few Citizens: they have bedlames of their own ſir,
And are mad at their own charges.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Who lies here?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Pray ye do not diſturb'em ſir, here lie ſuch youths
Will make you ſtart if they but dance their trenchmores.
Fetch out the boy, ſirha: hark. Shake Irons within.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Heigh boyes. Engl. mad-m.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Bownce, Scholler, Parſon.
Clap her o'th Star-bord: bounce: top the can, Jenkin.

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Dead ye dog, dead: do ye quarrell in my Kingdom?
Give me my trident.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Bownce, 'twixt wind and water,
Loaden with Mackrels: O brave meat.

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: My Sea horſes.
I'le charge the Northern wind, and break his bladder.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'le ſell my bels, before I be out-brav'd thus.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: What's he? what's he?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: A parſon ſir, a parſon,
That run madde for tythe Goſlings.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Green ſawte cure him.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.l: I'le curſe ye all, i'le excommunicate ye:
Thou Engliſh heretique, give me the tenth pot.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Sue me, i'le drink up all, bownce I ſay once more,
O, have I ſplit your mizen? blow, blow thou Weſt wind,
Blow till thou rive, and make the Sea run roaring.
I'le hiſſe it down againe with a bottle of Ale.

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Triton, why Triton.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Tritons drunk with metheglin.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Strike, ſtrike the ſurges, ſtrike.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Drink, drink, tis day light;
Drink, didle, didle, didle, drink, Parſon, proud Parſon:
A pigs tayle in thy teeth, and I defie thee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Give me ſome porridge, or i'le damne thee Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: How comes this Engliſh madde man here?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Alas thats no queſtion:
They are mad every where ſir;
Their fits are coole now: let 'em reſt. Ener Keepers and ſhee-foole.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Madde Gallants:
Moſt admirable mad: I love their faces.

sp.speaker: 1. K.
sp.l: Ye ſtinking whore: who knew of this? who lookd to him?
Pox take him, he was ſleepy when I left him,

sp.speaker: 2. K.
sp.l: Certain he made the foole drunk.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: How now who's this here?
Where is the boy?

sp.speaker: 1. Keep.
sp.l: The boy ſir?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I the boy, ſir.

sp.speaker: 1. K.
sp.l: Here's all the boyes we founde.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Theſe are his cloths.
But wher's the boy?

sp.speaker: She-f.
sp.l: The boy is gone a maying,
Hee'l bring me home a Cuckowes neſt; do ye hear Maſter
I put my cloths off, and I dizend him,
And pind a plumb in's forehead, and a feather,
And buſs'd him twice, and bid him go ſeek his fortune:
He gave me this fine money, and fine wine too,
And bid me ſop: and gave me theſe trim cloths too,
And put 'em on.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Is this the boy you would ſhew?

sp.speaker: She-f.
sp.l: I'le give you two pence Maſter.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Am I foold of all ſidies?
I met a foole i'th woods, they ſaid ſhe dwelt here,
In a long pied coat.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: That was the very boy, ſir.

sp.speaker: She.f.
sp.l: I, I, I, I gave him leave to play forſooth,
Hee'l come again to morrow, and bring peſcods.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I'le bring your bones.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pox o' your fooles, and bedlams,
Plague o' your owls and apes.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Pray ye ſir, be tamer,
We cannot help this preſently: but we ſhal know;
I'le recompence your cares too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Know me a pudding.
You juggle, and ye fidle: fart upon ye:
I am abuſed.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Pray ye ſir. Welch mad|man.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And I will be abuſed ſir,
And yon ſhall know I am abuſed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Whaw, Mr. Keeper.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pox o' thy whawes, and thy whyms,
Pox o' thy urſhip.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Give me ſome Ceeze, and Onions: give me ſome waſh-brew,
I have — in my bellies: give me abundance,
Pendragon was a Shentleman, marg you ſir,
And the Organs at Rixum were made by revelations,
There is a ſpirit blowes, and blowes the bellowes,
And then they ſing.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: What Moon-calſ's this? what dreame?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Pray ye ſir obſerve him,
He is a mountaineere, a man of Goteland.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: I will beate thy face as black as a blew-clout,
I will leave no more ſheet in thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: He will not hurt ye.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Give me a great deale of guns: thou art the devils,
I know thee by thy tayles: poor Owei.'s hungry,
I will pig thy bums full of bullets.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: This is the rareſt raſcall,
He ſpeakes as if he had butter-milk in's mouth,
Is this any thing a kin to th' Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: The elder brother, ſir,
He run mad becauſe a rat eate up's cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: H'ad a great deale of reaſon ſir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Baſilus manus, is for an old codpice, mark ye,
I will borrow thy unſhips whore, to ſeale a Letter.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Now he growes villanous.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Me thinks he's beſt now.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: He ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Sir, he muſt.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: I will ſing, and dance:
Do any thing.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Wilt thou declaime in greek?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Away with the foole,
And whip her ſoundly ſirah.

sp.speaker: She-f.
sp.l: I'le tell no more tales. Exit

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Or wilt thou fly i'th ayre?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.l: Do, and i'le catch thee,
And like a wiſp of hay, i'le whirle, and whirle thee,
And puſſe thee up: and puff thee up.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: I'le ſave thee,
And thou ſhalt fall into the Sea, ſoft, ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: I'le get upon a mountaine and call my Country|men.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: They all grow wild: away with him for heaven ſake,
Sir, ye are much too blame.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: No, no, tis brave ſir,
Ye have cozend me; i'le make you madde.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: In with him,
And lock him faſt.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I'le ſee him in his lodging. Exit

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: What meanes this Gentleman? En. Julletta

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He's in: have at him,
Are you the Maſter, ſir?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: What would you with him?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I have a buſines from the Duke of Medina,
Is there not an old Gentleman come lately in?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Yes, and a wild one too; But not a priſoner.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Did you obſerve him well? tis like he may be.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I have ſeen younger men of better temper.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have hit the cauſe I come for: ther's a letter
Pray ye peruſe it well: I ſhall be wi' ye;
And ſodainly, I fear not: finley, daintely,
I ſhall ſo feed your fierce vexation,
And raiſe your worſhips ſtormes: J ſhall ſo niggle ye,
And juggle ye, and fiddle ye, and firck ye:
I'le make ye curſe the houre yet vext a woman;
I'le make ye ſtake, when our ſex, are but ſounded:
For the Lords ſake, we ſhall have him at; I long to ſee it
As much as for my wedding night: I gape after it.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: This Letter ſayes the Gentleman is lunatique
I half ſuſpected it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tis very true ſir,
And ſuch prancks he has plaid.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: He's ſome great man,
The Duke commands me with ſuch care to look to him,
And if he grow too violent, to correct him,
To uſe the ſpeedieſt meanes for his recovery,
And thoſe he muſt finde ſharpe.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The better for him:

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: How got ye him hither?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: With a train, I told him:
He's in love with a boy, there lies his mellancholly.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Hither he came to ſeek one.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes, J ſent him,
Now had we dealt by force, we had never brought him.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Here was a boy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: He ſaw him not?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: He was gon firſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It is the better; looke you to your charge well:
Ile ſee him lodged, for ſo the duke commanded me
He will be very rough.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We are uſd to that ſir,
And we as rough as he, if he give occaſion.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You will find him gainfull, but be ſure ye curb him,
And get him if ye can fairely to his lodging, Enter Alphonſo.
I am afraid ye will not.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We muſt ſweat then.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: What doſt thou talk to me of noyſes? i'le have more noyſe
I'le have all looſe, and all ſhall play their prizes;
Thy Maſter has let looſe the boy I lookt for
Baſely convaid him hence.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Will ye go out ſir?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I will not out: I will have all out with' me, Shake Irons
I'le have thy Maſter in; he's only madde here.
And rogues, ile have ye all whipt: heigh mad boyes, mad boyes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Do you perceive him now?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Tis too apparant.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am glad ſhe is gon: he raves thus.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Do you hear ſir,
Pray will ye make leſſe ſtir, and ſee your chamber,
Call in more help; and make the cloſſet ready.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I thought he was mad: ile have on● long laſh at ye.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: My chamber? where my chamber why my chamber
Wher's the young boy?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Nay pray ye ſir be more modeſt
For your own credit ſake: the people ſee ye,
And I would uſe ye with the beſt.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Beſt, hang ye
What doſt thou think me madde?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Pray, and be civill,
Heaven may deliver ye.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Into a rogues hands.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: You do but draw more miſery upon ye,
And adde to your diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Get from me.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: No ſir,
You muſt not be left ſo: bear your ſelf civilly,
And twill be better for ye: ſwell not, nor chafe not.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I am a Gentleman, and a neighbour, raſcall.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: A great deale the more pity: I have heard of ye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Excellent Maſter.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: The Duke is very tender too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Am I lunatique? am I run madde?
What doſt thou talk to me of Dukes, and Devils,
Why do the people gape ſo?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Do not anger 'em,
But go in quietly, and ſlip in ſoftly
They will ſo tew ye, els, I am commanded ſir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Why, prethee why?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Ye are dog-mad: you perceive it not
Very far madde: and whips wil ſcant recover ye.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Ha▪ whips?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I whips, and ſore whips, and ye were a Lord ſir,
If ye be ſtubborne here:

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Whips? what am I grown.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O I could burſt: hold, hold, hold, hold o'both ends,
How h● lookes, pray heaven, he be not madde indeed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I do not perceive I am ſo; but if you think it,
Nor I▪le be hangd if't be ſo.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Do you ſee this ſir? Irons brought in
Down with that devill in ye.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Indeed I am angry,
But ile containe my ſelfe: O I could burſt now,
And teare my ſelfe, but theſe rogues will torment me,
Madde in mine old dayes? make mine owne afflictions?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: What doe you mutter ſir?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nothing, ſir, nothing;
I will goe in, and quietly, moſt civilly:
And good ſir, let none of your tormentors come about me,
You have a gentle face; they look like Dragons.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Be civill and be ſafe: come, for theſe two daies
Ye muſt eate nothing neither: twill eaſe your fits ſir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Twill ſtarve me ſir; but I muſt beare it joyfully.
I may ſleepe?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Yes, a little: go in with theſe men.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O miſerable me! Exit.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Ile follow preſently.
You ſee tis done ſir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ye have done it handſomely,
And ile inform the Duke ſo: Pray ye attend him;
Let him want nothing, but his will.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: He ſhall not,
And if he be rebellious—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Never ſpare him:
H'as fleſh, and hide enough, he loves a whipping.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: My ſervice to his Grace. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I ſhall commend it.
So, thou art faſt: I muſt goe get ſome freſh roome
To laugh, and caper in: O how it tickles me!
O how it tumbles me with joy! thy mouths ſtopt:
Now if I can doe my Miſtris good, I am Sainted. Exit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now, o' my conſcience, we have loſt him utterly,
He's not gon home: we heard from thence this morning,
And ſince our parting laſt at Rodorigo's,
You know what ground we have travel'd.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: He's aſleep ſure:
For if he had been awake, we ſhould have met with him:
'Faith let's turn back, we have but a fruitleſſe journey;
And to hope further of Alindas recovery,
(For ſure ſhe'l rather periſh then returne)
Is but to ſeeke a Moth i'th Sunne.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We'l on ſure;
Something we'l know, ſome cauſe of all this fooling,
Make ſome diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Which way ſhall we caſt then,
For all the Champion Country, and the villages,
And all thoſe ſides?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We'l croſſe theſe woods a while then:
Here if we faile, we'l gallop to Segonia
Add if we light of no news there, heare nothing;
We'l even turn fairly home, and coaſt the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: He may be ſicke, or faln into ſome danger;
He has no guide, nor no man to attend him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He's well enough, he has a travel'd body,
And though he be old, he's tough, and will endure well;
But he is ſo violent to finde her out,
That his anger leads him a thouſand wild gooſe chaſes:
Ile warrant he is well.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Shall we part company?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: By no means, no: that were a ſullen buſineſſe:
No pleaſure in our journey: Come, let's croſſe here firſt,
And where we finde the paths, let them direct us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why are you ſtill ſo fearfull of me, Lady?
So doubtfull of my faith, and honeſt ſervice?
To hide your ſelfe from me, to fly my company?
Am I not yours? all yours? by this light you ſhake ſtill;
Do ye ſuſpect me falſe? did I ever faile ye?
Doe you think I am corrupted? baſe? and treacherous?
Lord, how ye look! Is not my life tyde to ye?
And all the power I have to ſerve, and honour ye?
Still do ye doubt? ſtill am I terrible?
I will not trouble ye: good Heaven preſerve ye,
And ſend ye what ye wiſh: I will not ſee ye,
Nor once remember I had ſuch a Miſiris.
I will not ſpeak of ye, nor name Alinda,
For feare you ſhould ſuſpect I would betray ye:
Goodneſſe and peace conduct ye.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Prethee pardon me,
I know thou art truly faithfull: and thou art welcome,
A welcome partner to my miſeries;
Thou knowſt I love thee too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have thought ſo, Lady.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Alas, my feares have ſo diſtracted me
I durſt not truſt my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come, pray ye think better,
And caſt thoſe by: at leaſt conſider, Lady,
How to prevent 'em: pray ye put off this fooles coate;
Though it have kept ye ſecret for a ſeaſon,
Tis known now, and will betray ye; your arch enemy
Roderigo is abroad: many are looking for ye.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I know it: and thoſe many I have cozen'd:

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You cannot ſtill thus.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I have no meanes to ſhift it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have: and ſhift you too. I lay laſt night
At a poore widows houſe here in the Thicket,
Whether I will conduct ye, and new ſhape ye,
My ſelfe too to attend ye.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: What meanes haſt thou?
For mine are gone.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Feare not, enough to ſerve ye;
I came not out ſo empty.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Prethee tell me;
(For thou haſt ſtroke a kind of comfort through me.)
When ſaw'ſt thou Roderigo?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Even this morning,
And in theſe woods: take heed, h'as got a new ſhape.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: The habit of a Pilgrime? yes, I know it,
And I hope ſhall prevent it; was he alone?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No Madam, and which made me wonder mightily,
He was in company with that handſome Pilgrime,
That ſad ſweet man.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: That I forgot to give to?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The ſame, the very ſame, that you ſo pittied,
A man as fit to ſuit his villanies.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And did they walke together?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Wondrous civilly.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Talke, and diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I thinke ſo, for I ſee 'em
Make many ſtands, and then embrace each other.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: The Pilgrime is betraid, a Judas dwels with him,
A Simon, that will ſeem a Saint to choake him.
Canſt thou but ſhew me this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Lord how ſhe trembles!
Not thus, for all the world, ye are undone then;
But let's retire, and alter, then we'l walke free;
And then ile ſhew ye any things.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Come, good wench,
And ſpeedily: for I have ſtrang faiths working,
As ſtrange feares too, ile tell thee all my life then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come quick, ile conduct ye, and ſtill ſerve ye,
And doe not feare; hang feare, it ſpoiles all projects.
This way; Ile be your guide. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Uſe all your ſports,
All your ſolemnities; tis the Kings day to morrow.
His birth day, and his marriage, a glad day,
A day we ought to honour, all.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: We will ſir,
And make Segonia ring with our rejoycings.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Be ſumptuous, but not riotous; be bounteous,
But not in drunken Bacchanals: free to all ſtrangers,
Eaſie, and ſweet in all your entertainments,
For tis a Royall day admits no rudeneſſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip will do us the honour to be here your ſelfe,
And grace the day?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Tis a maine part of my ſervice.

sp.speaker: 3 Cit.
sp.l: I hope your honour has taken into your conſideration
The miſeries we have ſuffered by theſe Out-laws,
The loſſes, howrly feares; the rude abuſes
Strangers that travell to us are daily loaden with
Our daughters, and our wives complaints.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am ſorry for't,
And have Commiſſion from the King to eaſe it:
You ſhall not be long vext.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Had we not wals, ſir,
And thoſe continually man'd too with our watches,
We ſhould not have a bit of meat to feed us.
And yet they are our friends, and we muſt think ſo,
And entertaine 'em ſo ſometimes, and feaſt 'em,
And ſend 'em loden home too, we are loſt elſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: They'l come to Church amongſt us, as we hope Chriſtians,
When all their zeale is but to ſteale the Chalices;
At this good time now, if your Lordſhip were not here,
To awe their violence with your authority,
They would play ſuch gambals.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Are they grown ſo heady?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: They would drink up all our Wine, piſſe out our Bonfires;
Then, like the drunken Centaures, have at the faireſt,
Nay, have at all: fourſcore and ten's a Goddeſſe,
Whilſt we, like fooles, ſtand ſhaking in our cellars.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Are they ſo fierce upon ſo little ſufferance?
Ile give 'em ſuch a purge, and ſuddenly.
Verdugo, after this ſolemnity is over
Call on me for a charge of men, of good men,
To ſee what houſe theſe knaves keep: of good ſouldiers,
As ſturdy as themſelves: that dare diſpute with 'em,
Dare walk the woods as well as they, as fearleſſe,
But with a better faith belabour 'em;
Ile know what claim they have to their poſſeſſion.
Tis pity of their Captaine Roderigo,
A wel-bred Gentleman, and a good ſouldier,
And one, his Majeſty has ſome little reaſon
To thank, for ſundry ſervices, and faire ones;
That long neglect bred this, I am ſorry for him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The hope of his eſtate keeps backe his pardon,
There's divers waſpes, that buz about that honey-box,
And long to lick themſelves full.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: True Verdugo,
Would he had but the patience to diſcerne it,
And policy to wipe their lips.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: To fetch him in ſir,
By violence, he being now no infane,
Will aske ſome bloody crowns. I know his people.
Are of his owne choice men, that will not totter,
Nor blench much at a Bullet; I know his order,
And though he have no multitude, h'as manhood;
The elder-twin to that too, ſtaid experience.
But if he muſt be forced, ſir, —

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: There's no remedy,
Unleſſe he come himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: That will be doubtfull.
Did you never hear yet of the Noble Pedro?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I cannot by no means; I think he's dead ſure;
The Court bewailes much his untimely loſſe:
The King himſelfe laments him.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: He was ſunke;
And if he be dead, he died happily,
He buried all he had in the Kings ſervice,
And loſt himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Well: if he be alive, Captaine,
(As hope ſtill ſpeaks the beſt) I know the Kings mind
So inwardly and full, he will be happy.
Come, to this preparation; when that's done,
The Outlaws expedition is begun.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: We'l contribute all to that, and help our ſelves too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How ſweet theſe ſolitary places are? how wantonly
The wind blowes through the leafes, and courts, and playes with 'em?
Will ye ſit down, and ſleep? the heat invites ye.
Harke how yond purling ſtream dances, and murmurs,
The Birds ſing ſoftly too: pray take ſome reſt, ſir.
I would faine wooe his fancie to a peace,
It labours high and haſtily upon him;
Pray ye ſit, and Ile ſit by.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I cannot ſleep friend,
I have thoſe watches here admit no ſlumbers.
Saw ye none yet?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: No creature.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What ſtrange Muſicke
Was that we heard afar off?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I cannot gueſſe;
Twas loud, and ſhrill: ſometimes it ſhew'd hard by us,
And by and by the ſound fled as the wind does;
Here's no inhabitants.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: It much delighted me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: They talke of Faeries, and ſuch demi-devils,
This is as fine a place to dance their gambols.—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Me thought I heard a voyce. Muſick & Birds.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: They can ſing admirably,
They never loſe their maiden-heads: I would foole any away
To make him merry now: methinks yond rocks yonder
Shew like inchanted Cels, where they inhabit.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Tis here againe, harke gentle Roderigo,
Hark, hark: O ſweet, ſweet, how the Birds record too!
Marke how it flies now every way. O love,
In ſuch a harmony art thou begotten,
In ſuch ſoft Ayre, ſo gentle, lul'd and nouriſh'd.
O my beſt Miſtris!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How he weeps! deere Heaven
Give him his hearts content, and me forgive too.
I muſt melt too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The Birds ſing lowder, ſweeter,
And every note they emulate one another?
Lie ſtill and heare: Theſe when they have done their labours,
sp.stage: Enter Alinda and Juletta, like old women.
sp.l: Their pretty ayres, fall to their reſts, enjoy 'em.
Nothing rocks Love aſleeep, but death.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thoſe there, thoſe, thoſe things that come upon us,
Thoſe grandame things, thoſe ſtrange antiquities.
Did not I ſay theſe words begot ſtrange wonders?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now ye may view 'em.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The men ye long'd for,
Here they are both: now ye may boldy talke with 'em,
And never be gheſſ'd at: be not afraid, nor faint not;
They wond●r at us; let's maintaine that wonder;
Shake not, but what ye purpoſe doe diſcreetly,
And from your tongue i'le take my part.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Iul
sp.l: There: before ye, there, doe not turne coward Miſtreſſe,
If ye doe love, carry your Love out handſomely.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: 'Tis he and Roderigo; what a peace
Dwels in their faces, what a friendly calme
Crownes both their ſoules?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: They ſhow as if they were mortall,
They come upon us ſtill.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Be not afraid, man,
Let 'em be what they wil, they cannot hurt us,

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That thing ith' Button'd-Cap lookes terribly.
She has Guns in her eyes, the devils Ingeneer.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Come, ſtand, and let's goe meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Goe you firſt.
I have leſſe faith: when I have ſaid my Prayers—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There needs no feare, haile reveren'd dames.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Good ev'en.
What doe ye ſeeke?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: We would ſeek happier fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That little devill has maine need of a Barber,
What a trim beard ſhe has?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Seek 'em, and make 'em,
Lie not ſtill, nor longer here,
Here inhabits naught but feare.
Be conſtant good, in faith be clear,
Fortune will waite ye every where.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Whether ſhould we goe? for we beleeve thy Reverence,
And next obey.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Goe to Segonia.
And there before the Altar pay thy vowes,
Thy gifts, and Prayers: unload thy heavines,
To morrow ſhed thy teares, and gaine thy ſuit,
Such honeſt noble ſhowres, ne're wanted fruit.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Stand you out too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I ſhall be hang'd, or whipt now:
Theſe know, and theſe have power.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: See how he ſhakes.
A ſecure conſcience never quakes,
Thou haſt been ill; be ſo no more,
A good retreat is a great ſtore.
Thou haſt commanded men of might,
Command thy ſelfe, and then thou art right,

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Command thy will: thy foule deſires.
Put out and quench thy unhallowed fires:
Command thy mind, and make that pure;
Thou art wiſe then, valiant, and ſecure.
A bleſſing then thou maiſt beget.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A curſe elſe that ſhall never ſet
Will light upon thee: Say thy Prayers,
Thou haſt as many ſins, as haires.
Thou art a Captain, let thy men
Be honeſt, and good thoughts, and then
Thou maiſt command, and lead in chiefe,
Yet thou art bloody, and a theife.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What ſhall doe? I doe confeſſe.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Retire,
And purge thee perfect in his fire:
His life obſerve; live in his Schoole,
And then thou ſhalt put off the foole.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Pray at Segonia too, and give
Thy Offrings up, repent, and live.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Away, away: enquire no more, within Muſicke
Doe this, ye are rich, elſe fooles, und poore;
What Muſick's this?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Retire? 'tis ſome neat Joy,
In honour of the Kings great day: they wonder,
This comes in right to confirme their reverence.
Away, away, let them admire, it makes
For our advantage: how the Captaine ſhakes? Exit.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This was the Muſick.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Yes, yes, how I ſweat!
I was never ſo deſerted; ſure theſe woods
Are onely inhabited with rare dreames, and wonders;
I would not be a knave againe, a villaine:
Lord, how I loath it now: for theſe know all Sir,
And they would finde me out.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They are excellent women,
Deepe in their knowledge, friend.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I would not be traytor,
And have theſe of my Jury; how light I am,
And how my heart laughes now me thinkes within me?
Now I am Catechiz'd, I would ever dwell here,
For there is a kinde of Court of Reformation;
Had I beene ſtubborn friend.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They would have found it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And then they would have handled me a new way,
The devils dump had been danced then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Let's away
And doe their great Commands, and do 'em handſomely:
Contrite, and true, for I beleeve Roderigo,
And conſtantly beleeve, we ſhall be happy.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: So you doe well; fall edge or flat O my ſide;
All I can ſtagger at is the Kings Anger,
Which if it come, I am prepar'd to meet it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The King has mercy, friend, as well as Juſtice:
And when you fall: no more.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I hope the faireſt. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: We have told ye what he is: what time we have ſought him:
His nature, and his name: the ſeeming Boy too,
Ye had here, how, and what by your own relation,
All circumſtances we have cleer'd: That the Duke ſent him
We told ye how impoſſible; he knowes him not;
That he is mad himſelfe, and therefore fit
To be your Priſoner, we dare ſwear againſt it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Take heed Sir, be not madder then you would make him;
Though he be raſh, and ſuddain (which is all his wildenes)
Take heed ye wrong him not: he is a Gentleman,
And ſo muſt be reſtor'd and cleer'd in all points;
The King ſhall be a Judge elſe.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: 'Twas ſome trick
That brought him hither: the Boy, and letter counterfeit,
Which ſhall appear, if ye dare now detain him.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I dare not Sir; nor will not: I beleeve ye,
And will reſtore him up: had I known ſooner
H'ad been a neighbour, and the man you ſpeak him,
(Though as I live, he carried a wild ſeeming)
My Service, and my ſelfe had both attended him
How I have us'd him, let him ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let's in, and viſit him:
Then to the holy Temple: there pay our duties,
And ſo wee'le take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I'le waite upon ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: This to devotion ſacred be,
This to the Kings proſperity,

l.hi: This to the Queen, and Chaſtity.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Theſe Oblations firſt we bring
To purge our ſelves: Theſe to the King.

l.hi: To love, and beautie theſe: now ſing.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: Holy Altar, daigne to take
Theſe for our ſelves: For the Kings ſake
And honour theſe: Theſe ſacred lye
To Vertue, Love, and Modeſty

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: For our ſelves firſt, thus we bend
Forgive us heaven, and be our friend:

l.hi: And happy fortune to us ſend.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: To the King, honour, and all Ioy,
Long, and happy from annoy.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Proſperous be all his dayes
Every new houre, a new praiſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Every minute thus be ſeene,

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: And thouſand honours Crowne the Queene. Muſick. Enter Alphonſo, Curio, Seberto.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Come to the Altar: let, us do our duties.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I have almoſt forgot a Church.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Kneele reverently.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: For my loſt wits (let me ſee)
Firſt J pray: and ſecondly
To be at home againe, and free,
And if I travell more, hang me,
For the King, and for the Queene,
That they may be wiſe, and ſeene
Never in the Mad-mans Jnne.
For my daughter, I would pray
But ſhe has made a holly-day,
And needs not my devotion now
Let her take her own courſe (heaven,)
Whether it be od, or even. Muſick. Enter Alinda, & Iuletta like Shepheards.
And if that pleaſe not, take her you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A ſhort, and ſweet Meditation: what are theſe here?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Haile to this ſacred place,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: They are all here, Madam:
No violence dare touch here; be ſecure:
My Bilbo Maſter too: how got he looſe againe?
How lamentably he lookes: he has had diſcipline.
I dare not let him know my prancks.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe ſure.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: 'Tis certainly.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ha! doe I dazell?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: 'Tis the faire Alinda.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What wonder ſtand theſe ſtrangers in?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Her woman by her,
The ſame Sir, as I live,

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I had a daughter,
With ſuch a face once: ſuch eyes and noſe too,
Ha, let me ſee, 'tis wondrous like Alinda,
Their devotion ended, I'le marke 'em and neerer.
And ſhe had a Filly that waited on her:
Juſt with ſuch a favour,
Doe they keepe Goats now?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Thus we kneele, and thus we pray
A happy honour, to this day,
Thus our Sacrifice we bring
Ever happy to the King.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Theſe of Purple, Damask greene
Sacred, to the vertuous Queene
Here we hang.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: As theſe are now
Her glories ever ſpring, and ſhow,
Theſe for our ſelves: our hopes, and loves,
Full of pincks, and Ladies gloves,
Of hartes-eaſe too, which we would faine
As we labour for, attaine;
Heare me heaven, and as I bend,
Full of hope: ſome comfort ſend.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Heare her: heare her: if there be
A ſpotles Sweetnes, this is ſhe. Muſick.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Now Roderigo ſtand.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: He that devides ye
Devides my life too.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Pedro, Noble Pedro.
Doe not you know your friend?

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: I know, and honour ye.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Lady this leave i'le crave, pray be not angry,
I will not long devide you: how happy Pedro,
Would all the Court be now, might they be hold thee?
Might they but ſee you thus and thus embrace you?
The King will be a joyfull man beleeve it
Moſt joyfull Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I am his humble Servant.
Nay, good Sir, ſpeake your will, I ſee you wonder, one eaſie word from you—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I dare ſay nothing
My tongue's a new tongue Sir, and knowes his tither,
Let her doe what ſhe pleaſe, I dare doe nothing,
I have been damn'd for doing, will the King know him?
That fellow there, will he reſpect and honour him?
He has been look'd upon they ſay: will he own him?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Yes certainly and grace him, ever honour him,
Reſtore him every way, he has much lamented him.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Is't your will too? this is the laſt time of asking.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I am ſure, none elſe ſhall touch her, none elſe enjoy her.
If this, and this hold.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: You had beſt begin the game then, I have no title in her,
Pray take her, and diſpatch her, and commend me to her,
And let me get me home, and hope I am ſober:
Kiſſe, kiſſe, it muſt be thus: ſtand up Alinda,
I am the more Childe, and more need of bleſſing.
Ye had a waiting woman, one Iuletta,
A pretty deſperate thing, juſt ſuch another
As this ſweet Lady; we call'd her nimble chaps.
I pray is this the party?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No indeed Sir,
She is at home; I am a little Foot-Boy,
That walke a nights, and fright old Gentlemen;
Make 'em looſe Hats and Cloakes.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And Horſes too.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Sometimes I doe Sir, teach 'em the way through ditches;
And how to breake their worſhips ſkins, and notes
Againſt old broken Stiles, and Stumps.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: A fine art.
I feele it in my bones yet.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am a Drum Sir,
A Drum at mid-night, ran tan tan tan tan Sir,
Do you take me for Iuletta? I am a Page Sir,
That brought a letter from the Duke of Medina
To have one ſenior Alphonſo, juſt ſuch another
As your old worſhip worm'd for running mad Sir.
Alas, you are miſtaken,

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou art the devill,
And ſo thou haſt uſed me,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am any thing,
An old woman, that tels fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Iul
sp.l: And frights good people,
And ſends them to Segonia for their fortunes:
I am ſtrange ayers, and excellent ſweet voyces.
I am any thing, to doe her good beleeve me;
She now recovered, and her wiſhes crown'd
I am Iuletta againe, pray ſir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I dare not doe otherwiſe, for fear thou ſhould'ſt ſtill follow me,
Prethee be forgiven, and I prethee forgive me too:
And if any of you, will marry her.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: No I beſeech you Sir;
My Miſtreſſe is my husband, with her I'le dwell ſtill,
And when you play any more prancks you know where to have me.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: You know him Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Know him, and much lament him:
The Kings incens'd much, much Sir, I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Noble Governour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: But ſince he is your friend, and now appeares,
In honour of this day and love to you ſir:
I'le try the power I have, to the pinch i'le put it;
Here's my hand Roderigo, I'le ſet you faire again.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And here's mine, to be true, and full of Service.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Your people too, ſhall have their generall pardons,
We'll have all peace and love.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: All ſhall pray for you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: To my houſe now, and ſuite you to your worths;
Off with theſe weeds, and appeare glorious:
Then to the Prieſt, that ſhall attend us here,
And this be ſtil'd Loves new and happy yeare.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The Kings and Queenes, two noble honors meet,
To grace this day, two true loves at their feet

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Well well, ſince wedding will come after wooing,
Give me ſome Roſe-Mary, and let's be going.
